Despite my respect for Soulsborne games, I've never invested in beating any of them after regular NG. Armored Core VI, though was rent free in my head until I had not finished all of the endings.

Great sense of verticality, ridiculously satisfying weapons with fun movesets, rewarding and enjoyable bosses. The other wonderful trait of the game is how everything fits apocalyptic tone of the game: setting, narrative, characters, soundtrack.

It is reasonable to criticise the game though - its difficult curve seems off. A lot of segments may seem too simple, and some of the bosses in may be brutally hard in comparison. It is fairly easy to find the build, which can break the game. Also I really wish that customisation had more variety for limbs and flexibility for weapons (it is quite sad that there is no option to have dual melee weapon builds).

If some of those and other aspects were tweaked, it could have been easily a perfect game. Anyway, it is still another gem from 2023. If you haven't beat the game yet, do not put it on the shelf after its first completion, you won't regret it!
Very fun game, only play if you have a tolerance for frustration though.

I love this game. It has one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard. It's fun, with fast-paced cinematic game play. It's optimized and runs amazingly well for how visually stunning it looks. The customization is excellent and there are many different play styles. It's hard, but not too hard, and it's fair. People may be put off by the mission structure of levels, but I found it a refreshing change of pace from the endless open-world games we see nowadays. Just a great game overall. My only complaint is I wish there was more of it.

Can't find enough words to describe how this game feels. It doesn't have that grandiose epicness of Dark Souls. It's a dramatic, grounded, depressive world, where you happen to be a mercenary who got caught up in fire. This game is hard, it requires to think, to combine, to customise and analyse your decisions about choosing parts for your AC. And this is where i spend most of my time - in the garage, changing parts, making configurations. This is what i love in AC games. But also, the story, the emotional part behind it, even if it's not that noticeable for the majority, the atmosphere just hits. 

It might not be for everyone, it might be a niche game, but i infinitely glad i found that niche, because AC connects with me on a very deep level, however silly it might sound.

[u]The short: I am happy with my purchase. So much that I paid for the game full price, twice.[/u]

Armored Core as a series are the definitive mecha games. They set the standard for robot-themed customization and sorties. The franchise has come a long way from the PlayStation 1 era, and Armored Core 6 (AC6) has been a long time in waiting since the last entry, Armored Core V / Verdict Day on the PS3.

The series has gone through several reboots in game design, and AC6 is the latest reboot. To provide some perspective, I have played the majority of the Armored Core games, but most notably, I have not played AC4 / For Answer.

AC6 feels like a solid baseline as a new era in the series. That is to say, It almost feels like a proof-of-concept to see how this new design would work. A very good concept, albeit, with some imperfections here and there. The game introduces a few new mechanics, some of which can be particularly divisive, such as Hard Lock-On and Stagger. Hopefully in their next installment, these mechanics can be smoothened out to be a bit less on the controversial side.

On the other hand, generally speaking, the game feels incredibly smooth to play. When I first powered on the game, I was pleasantly surprised to find that piloting the mech almost felt like trying to drive a new kind of vehicle. It took a little adjustment in the beginning, but quickly became second nature. The movement and performance of your mech depends entirely on how you build it. Variety in this game is incredible. Speaking of variety, even the game's mission and boss designs encourage you to try out different loadouts to make things easier (or more difficult) for yourself.

Comparatively to previous AC games, the story in this one seems to be presented in a way that is easier to follow, which I would consider to be a good thing, personally. The characters and voice acting are also incredible, even if you never get to see the people themselves. While I understand that this is likely an intentional means of presenting the story, I still wished that for once we could actually see or interact with some people. There are some missions that have absolutely incredible set pieces as well, which definitely impressed me from time to time.

This game does have some multiplayer in the form of PvP, but understand that this primarily a single-player focused game. Personally, I was hoping for more of a multiplayer experience, having come from ACV and loving that one, but sorely found it lacking here. By all means, this is not a bad thing if you prefer single-player games, especially since this one has fairly good replay value in the form of New Game +. However, if you are a multi-player gamer like myself, for the most part, you won't find it here.

[u]The Negatives:[/u]
- Lacking multiplayer. At launch, you had to manually enter player rooms. The game didn't even have PvP matchmaking 'till it was patched in later. No co-op.
- Questionable weapon balance. You could say that this is par for the course in From's games, as there will always be one weapon that is better than something else. However, I have seen guns that have single-handedly trivialized the entire game.
- Missing weapons / parts from previous games. Not having sniper cannons and the like, in favor of the new close-quarters combat stagger system, definitely sucks.

[u]Final Thoughts:[/u]
This game feels masterwork in mech design. However, I do feel like this entry is more of a foundation to build upon for Armored Core 7 and beyond. And I certainly hope that is the case, that the next AC game will be even bigger and better, having taken feedback from the new mechanics introduced in this game. I will be eagerly awaiting the next game, and I hope that From Software decides to involve more multiplayer aspects such as co-op, and a more robust PvP environment.

Autobots roll out

• FromSoftware's best (and by far most approachable) game
• Great mood and atmosphere as you would expect
• Interesting story and is remixed in New Game+ and New Game++ with a bunch of surprising twists
• Most of the story is told through voice comms; very smart use of budget and gives it a real mood
• Some of the best English voice acting in a game ever

• Extremely responsive, speedy, and polished combat; zero Souls jank
• Incredible level of mech customisation, right down to creating custom decals
• Loads of parts to create your mechs with, and fairly good part diversity
• That said, I wish there were even more parts to play around with

• The game is very good about communicating what different parts do
• The UI is well designed and makes it very easy to experiment with parts and builds
• Best of all, the game WILL make you try different builds depending on the mission
• You'll eventually ascend to mecha pilot GOD status and wonder how certain bosses ever gave you trouble

• Mission-based structure, which makes it very easy to pick up and play
• Excellent mission diversity; the game constantly manages to surprise you
• Mission maps are very well designed and never feel repetitive despite re-use
• A lot of the maps can feel very complex and layered and fun to explore

• I roleplayed the absolute heck out of Armored Core 6
• I created over 20 mechs, and my own made-up corporations with their own backstories
• The setting and mood are just that engaging for a mecha enthusiast
• This game is my comfort food; I played it for well over 200 hours

Armored Core VI: Fires of Rubicon is a breathtaking return to form for the beloved mech combat franchise, delivering a thrilling blend of deep customization, intense action, and a rich, atmospheric narrative. From the moment you step into your mech, the game immerses you in a dystopian world filled with stunning visuals and intricate details that showcase the sheer scale of both the environments and the towering machines you pilot. The gameplay is an exhilarating mix of fast-paced combat and strategic planning. The controls are tight and responsive, allowing for fluid movement and precise aiming, which is crucial when engaging in the game's challenging missions.

The level of customization is astounding—players can tweak every aspect of their mech, from weapons and armor to mobility systems. This depth encourages experimentation, enabling you to find the perfect setup that suits your playstyle. Graphically, Armored Core VI shines. The environments are richly designed, with diverse landscapes ranging from desolate urban ruins to sprawling industrial complexes. The lighting and particle effects during combat are breathtaking, making each skirmish feel dynamic and visceral. Coupled with a hauntingly atmospheric soundtrack and impactful sound design, the overall experience is nothing short of cinematic.

Armored Core 6 promises metal carnage and, if you can beat the boss of the tutorial, it does deliver... just not much more than that. 

The graphics are good enough but nothing to really praise as much of the scenery is a drab grey industrial theme save for maybe two or three zones.

The difficulty on a majority of missions feels laughably easy with the only exceptions being the bosses and enemy AC pilots. This leads to sudden difficulty spikes because the basic enemies are shredded like their made from paper while anything beyond that leads to either a sudden out of nowhere requirement of skill or an absolute wall of pain requiring several restarts.

Contrary to some what some reviews say (looking at you Alex from AngryJoeShow), This game DOES have a story which is delivered through well acted voiceovers about you and your main contact Walter work with and against two main corporations Balam and Arquebuss, fighting against rebels of the Rubicon Liberation Front and each other while making deals with a fourth shady "junkieyard" scavenger faction Reuse And Development or RAD, all while an AI Overseer ALLMIND monitors the entire situation. That said, the plot isn't too important for many of the minor missions and could possibly be ignored entirely though paying attention does explain why you are now fighting a giant Gillette Electric Razor snake and everyone is mad at you for ruining their field trip by not bringing the weapon specifically designed for this.

The gameplay progression is through a Select Mission structure with being forced to occasionally choose one mission over the others. Most missions are relatively simple with destroying all enemies, targeted objects, or collect the occasional MechGuffin all again with the exception of boss missions. Damage is less about raw damage and instead trying to stun your enemies by staggering them with enough damage to dish out bonus damage.

Control-Wise the game feels very fast paced and fluid with mouse and keyboard, the only major issue being when I first got it the hard lock would break the second you moved your move, but it seems that's been remedied with more leeway on mouse movement. Boost kick feels awkward no matter what, but you get used to it.

CUSTOMIZATION: What is a mech game without customization? By progressing through the story, collecting logs and completing battles for ALLMIND, you unlock parts to buy in the shop. The only real downside is how the best mission for grinding money in the game is the previously mentioned overgrown Motorized Shave Worm which is easy as hell if you got the super weapon or two of them, you'll just be doing it a lot.

The mech parts are almost all part of some set with the exceptions being the specialty legs which can drastically change your movement. You can tell the intended purpose of each set by which company built them, or just by looking at some of them. The sleek jetfighter set by Schnieder is the speedy paper machae, the heavy looking set by Dafeng set has high durability but sluggish. The Balam sets are well rounded but slightly better against munitions. The Arquebuss sets are designed for lasers. so on, so forth. No one full set feels too overpowered compared to the others but there are combinations by mixing sets that absolutely feel that way. 

Of the legs you have the standard Bipedal, the high jumping and auto jump-dashing Reverse Joint coming in light, medium and death-kick heavy. The vehicular "legs" being a heavy literal pretty-sure-it's-the-highest-armor-value Tank, a lightning fast wheelchair style tread set, and a hovercraft designed for aerial combat. Finally there's the Tetrapod legs in light, medium, and the not-quite-as-tanky-as-literal-tank-but-almost heavy all that have the ability to hover and glide around.

There are three flavors of weapon damage. Ballistic, Energy/Pulse/Laser/callitwhatever, and explosive, and a whole bunch of why to let your enemies sample each. There are even melee weapons and shields, though both are exclusively right side weapons with the melee being primary and shields being shoulders.
At the games release the meta was dual Heavy Shottys, dual Chainguns, and/or Songbird bazookas due to the stunlock meta and rifles felt very underwhelming. Things have changed and while the original meta is still good, it's nowhere near as broken and rifles feel much better to use damage wise though I am personally still not a fan of the slower firerate. Sniper rifles are almost non-existant and instead there are chargeable linear rifles which "kinda" are but they don't zoom or scope they just have longer target range. 
You like missiles? the game has missiles. lots of missiles. You have forward missiles, vertical takeoff missiles, delayed missiles, high yield missiles, laser missiles, 4 shot, 6 shot, 8 shot, ROTARY FIVE SHOT SALVO FOR 15 SHOT MISSILES. You have short missiles long missiles, bazookas, scuds, scatter, and so many more. You like missile? Game got missile.

Ultimately the game delivers on mech customization including stuff so detailed like making your own decals I won't bother going into because it's so freeform and customizable.

Would I say the game is worth the price? Eh. It's a very satisfying game, and you can do multiple runs to get different missions, parts, logs, and endings, but once you get all the parts and get all said endings, there isn't really anything left. There's PvP I guess but I've had a 50/50 shot of a stable or laggy connection and despite having a small handfull of good matches it wasn't really my thing.

If your're a diehard Fromsoft fan or just a hard fan of Armored Core or mech games in general, it's up to you if you want to pay the full price or wait for a discount. For all the casuals I'd say wait for a sale and see if you enjoy it before those two hours are up. Everything moves by fast enough that if you don't have a difficult time with the tutorial helicopter boss you'll get a good sense of whether or not you like it within those two hours. The helicopter is by far the easiest boss and there is no difficulty setting, so if you think it's too hard then you might not like it unless your a masochist.

Fires of Rubicon brings the beloved mech franchise back with a bang, delivering intense, fast-paced combat and deep customization options. Set on the planet Rubicon, the game lets you pilot towering mechs, engaging in high-stakes battles across stunning, desolate landscapes. The narrative is minimalist but effective, focusing on corporate greed, betrayal, and survival in a war-torn world.

The heart of the game lies in its combat, which rewards strategic thinking and reflexes. Players can tweak every aspect of their mechs, from weapons to mobility, allowing for endless experimentation. Boss fights are challenging and exhilarating, often pushing you to the edge with their scale and complexity.

While the difficulty may feel punishing at times, especially for newcomers, Fires of Rubicon captures the essence of the Armored Core series, offering a rewarding, highly customizable experience for mech enthusiasts and fans of FromSoftware’s challenging games alike.
Fast paced combat, in depth customisation, and a contender for my favourite FromSoftware game

Let me start off by saying I have never played any Armored Core game prior to this, and my knowledge of Gundam/Mecha is very limited. I came to this game as a fan of Fromsoftware and the Dark Souls trilogy. 

There is something so special about this game. the atmosphere, game play, art direction, musical score, and characters all work to completely suck you into this world. Rather than feeling like your just selecting missions from a menu or buying new parts from a list, every UI you interface with feels like it was painstakingly created to immerse you into the life of an independent mercenary here on Rubicon. 

I want to dedicate a section here just for this games Music. Every single song that plays while you are out on missions or just in the menu sets the theme perfectly. When it needs to be it is subdued, upbeat, or grand. Kota Hoshino Really outdid himself here. 

Customizing your AC is extremely fun. There are so many different weapons and builds to mess around with. I found myself swapping constantly as I unlocked new things, eager to try out new weapon combos I cooked up. 

[b] TLDR [/b] This is an amazing game even if you have never played something like it. I can't give it enough praise.

Overview: Armored Core 6 is more like a work of art and the experience is tailored with a specific audience in mind. It is not for the faint of heart (both in terms of the story and the difficulty curve) and not everyone will enjoy it. With that being said, I'd say it still has one of the best stories/campaigns out of most games I've played within the last decade. This is also my first experience of any Armored Core game.

Gameplay/Mechanics: 9/10
What I've been looking for in the Mecha genre was a game where actions were more deliberate and attacks feel like they have weight to them. The melee weapons definitely fit that role and require proper setup to be most effective. In fact getting the most damage out of any weapon is usually accomplished by first stunning/staggering the enemy through ACS buildup. This stun bar is a new mechanic to the series and not everyone is a fan of it, but I don't see much of an issue with it outside of multiplayer/network lag.
The movement speed is generally fast paced, but avoiding damage often requires precise timing and is essential to not dying horribly in this game. Certain enemies/bosses are definitely bullet sponges, but having the right loadout can make a big difference in both difficulty and how you play. My only real complaint is related to technical limitations or the game's netcode along with the requirement of a mod to play the campaign mode cooperatively with friends. Certain missions may also contain bugs and performance issues which may occasionally require you to restart the mission.

Difficulty: Lego Yoda Death Scream/10
The difficulty is not so much of a curve, but a series of brick walls at certain points in the game. The first one being a heavy attack helicopter designed for the express purpose of systematically removing game journalists from the gene pool along with my sanity. To be fair this is debatably the 3rd or 4th hardest boss in the game (due to the fact that your starting loadout is dogwater) and they decided to make it the tutorial boss. I am currently petitioning the local government to provide humanitarian aid in the form of MANPADS.

Story: 10/10
War is hell. Also wow cool robot!
The game has many interesting characters. While choices you make will significantly impact what happens to the world, many people are simply destined to die regardless of your choices. This game can occasionally hit you in the feels so I wouldn't get too attached to anyone (stop hurting me FromSoft). There are multiple endings. Not going to say too much else here to avoid talking about spoilers, but overall you can tell they put a lot of effort into making this game. 

Soundtrack: 9/10
"Please stop saying dumb things! You're not even making sense-"
HIGH AND DRY
I FLY HIGH
WATCH THAT SUN RISE
IN THE DAWN

Most of the soundtrack goes for a more atmospheric feel as opposed to earlier Armored Core games, but there's a few really good songs in there ("Rusted Pride", and "Contact with You" for example).

Slight Rant About Video Games and "Curated Experiences":
My criticism of many mainstream "AAA" games these days is they try way too hard to fit into a trope of "interactive storytelling" or attempting to be a "unique cinematic experience" to the point where it feels forced. A lot of publishers also tend to forget about the whole "video game" aspect of the media they are trying to produce. As a result of these trends (along with all the other monetization/marketing tactics which plague modern games), things often feel superficial because everyone is in the industry wants to appeal to a wider audience. 

"Finally Some Good ****ing Food":
AC6 is pretty much the exact opposite in every regard. It is unapologetic about what it is and who it is made for. The game is only supported by its own merits alone without all the various marketing gimmicks, monetization schemes, or live service battlepass seasonal nonsense which publishers use as a crutch to determine success. People were asking FromSoft to make a new Armored Core game for years and AC6 was made with this specific target audience in mind. AC6 does streamline some of the systems to make it more accessible for new players (at least from what I heard), and somehow managed to make the much sought after "cinematic experience" that other games wish they had. I was expecting a game with giant robots where the universal solution to most problems is the Pilebunker, not one of best singleplayer/cooperative campaigns since Halo 1 and 2.

Note on Multiplayer:
To be fair, I have not really tried the competitive multiplayer modes and mostly play cooperatively with a friend instead. While I cannot comment specifically on the PVP multiplayer, the Cooperative play mod essentially runs on the same logic as Elden Ring, where people can invade your missions unless you disable the feature. In my experience, 3 missions do not function as intended but only 2 of them require you to play solo. You may occasionally need to restart the "Prison Break" escort mission because sometimes the AI can bug out and fail to trigger specific objectives.

Having played almost every Armored Core game in the series, I have to say this game does a lot of things better, and a few more than that worse than the previous games in the series. The soundtrack is great, the gameplay is great, the story is really good, the characters are all great, but previous games in the series most definitely had a better soundtrack and gameplay. 

The game is fun, but certainly not quite the Armored Core game a lot of people were hoping for. Personally I have a strong preference to the 3rd and 4th generation's style of gameplay functioning more as a third person shooter, rather than a combo-focused fighting game with an Armored Core aesthetic.
Fights have always been a slog in the series, especially when not knowing how much health an enemy combatant has, but Armored Core 6 has decided to probably make a lot of fights a bit too easy. I've made many builds to fight bosses with in my own preferred way, and that's fun, but in the back of my mind I always have the thought of "Wow, I really could've done this a lot more easily with a pile-driver and 2x Zimmermans, huh."

This game punishes you for treating it like another game of the same series, in fact I really don't like this game's PvP, despite how addicting I find it. It always makes me think of how much fun I'd be having if they had ported Armored Core: for Answer to PC with well functioning net-play, I'd probably be having a lot more fun playing with friends and strangers that way. 
Rather than being in awe that someone's build is really cool and functional, I'm mad that I've died to another one-shot combo build that somehow staggered me after missing with whatever high-impact weapon they use by 200 meters.

Masaru Yamamura is a great game designer, but really I think he should focus on what made all the older games great, why their movement feels so good, that being staggered is not a fun thing to happen every fight, and that we really don't need more Dark Souls and Sekiro mechanics in Armored Core.

I miss Arms-Forts, I miss the silly punk-rock music from Nexus through Verdict Day, I miss the slow turn-speeds and the lock box from older games. 
I'm hoping their next game, Armored Core 6.5 or Armored Core 7, will take less from their recent titles, and truly bring back Armored Core. Doesn't need to be a new game even, re-releasing all the old games on Steam as Re-mastered titles or literally just the same game would go a long way to bring back some interest to this franchise, give people the opportunity to play these games online again so we can all experience it, or be brought back to a happier time for those nostalgic for it.

I know I complain a lot, but this game isn't a disappointment to me, it's probably everything I expected it to be, and that's a good thing. But I know they can do better if they avoid going for mass appeal again, unlike what FromSoftware did with Elden Ring. Take chances again, do the weird stuff that you used to do, more silly music, experiment with mechanics that probably not everyone will be on-board with, it's better than succumbing to apathy and making Dark Souls, again, but worse.

I've only played AC once on the PS2, and I can't remember anything from that game. I've never played any other FromSoftware games. They are just not my cup of tea. But this, this is good.

As far as smooth single player experiences this game is unmatched. Ill start with whats bad and go from there.

Plot - Well I wont lie is uninspiring at times, and a bit typical of AC game but that's really not what we are here for. It has some fun twists and great secrets, there is depth, but not too much depth that you find yourself overwhelmed or frustrated figuring things out. 

Atmosphere - This is where things pick up, players will feel caught up in the world building, level design, and buildup between bossfights. Really easy to get immersed in this game.

Gameplay - is VERY smooth. A lot closer ranged compared to past AC games but this is really made up for in how much more fluid the movement is in this game. Aiming, shooting, and moving all feel very organic and the player will really enjoy seeing improvement in their own movement as the game goes on.

Customization - Now as far as past AC games there are examples with more customization, however the variety of parts, weapons, and components for your mech is still nothing to scoff at. As far as fine tuning a perfect mech this game is a dream, complete down to being able to adjust the amount of wear and tear vs factory new shine on your paint job. You can not only make a mech that feels intuitive to your playstyle but you can spend hours making it look just perfect.
 
As a game primarily about mech building, testing, and fighting the updates released so far show that FROMSOFT does have interest in making sure there are viable, different ways to play which is an amazing sign,

PvP is lovely, while it can feel rock paper scissors at times you only really see this in low to mid rank lobbies. People will rage and leave comments on your profile though in ranked though hahaha.

All in all an amazing game, I hope to see some small improvements in the next installation, but really any armored core game after Verdict Day is a blessing :)

Armored Core 6: Fires of Rubicon is an amazing game with satisfying combat, tons of customization, and good replay value.

In this game, you can customize your "character" to fit your needs for a mission you are about to head into. Going against annoying flying drones? Bring missiles and exterminate them all at once with one salvo. Going against short range grounded enemies? Bring a leg unit that will help you hover while you pepper them with explosives.

You can also pit the abomination you created in your garage against numerous ACs in the Arena.

And if you are wondering about the boss encounters? It is glorious. Expect to be smashed by big bad mechs. Remember those drones your peppered with missiles? Remember those ground-based idiots who brought short range weapons against your flying quad-legs? Yeah, that's what you're gonna feel. Good luck.

The story though got the short end of the stick. This is not gonna be your cinematic video game with scripted scenarios. A lot of the story is gonna be delivered through on-screen dialogue. Mission briefings are gonna be through PowerPoint presentations. And sometimes, you are going to be left wondering "WTF am I supposed to do again?" and then proceed to murder everyone in your path towards the objective marker. Just remember at the start of the game, you are a mercenary and you will be hired by corporations to take on missions and get paid. This was my first armored core game after playing over 1000 hours of from software's other games (dark souls trilogy, bloodborne, sekiro, elden ring). I enjoyed 100%-ing this game, and it was nice to see a different style of game by from software.

The first thing is that this is not a "souls-like", it's an armored core game. I really enjoyed the different style of gameplay with short missions of intense combat. The gameplay also allows for fighting multiple enemies quite well. The build mechanic where you can easily switch parts of your mech works really well too. While the first 3 chapters I found relatively easy (but still very fun), there were some challenging boss fights towards the end of the game. I also think it's worth doing all three endings to experience all missions and boss fights. 

Overall, this is amazing game, it runs well, it's well designed, is very fun, and has good replay value.

First time playing an AC/mech game. There's a lot going on and it takes a while before you learn how to really pilot that mech, but then the game becomes buttery smooth. NG+ has a lot of tricks up its sleeve which makes it a certified fresh experience.

A true love letter to the mecha genre. Everything about the game screams flair and personality. Every AC part has its use so no two builds are going to be the same (unless you're always copying the meta). With up to 59 different missions, this game requires three total playthroughs for a full and complete experience. 

The game does allow you to fulfil that mecha power fantasy, but it will humble you here and there with some of the most cinematic and adrenaline inducing boss fights. So learning, adapting, and overcoming is key. Everything in this game can be beaten with anything. And with a wide selection of weapons to choose from, you're spoiled for choice.

More lazy Fromsoft trash; Input reading is atrocious and makes many weapons unusable; the stance bar is a completely unnecessary addition and just shows more of fromsoft's inability to innovate on any level. Many of the bosses suffer from fundamentally game breaking bugs. 

I don't expect many of the Fromsoft Fanboys to actually have ever played Armored core; but many of these missions are just lesser versions of those from previous AC games (the wall is the first mission in armored core 4 and 4 was hands down better - what little shreds of a coherent story exist are simply ripped from Mechwarriors 2 Mercenaries. 

Armored core is a series with some serious clout. But this is just elden ring in fancy robots- not an armored core game. I despise fromsoft's desire to productize every one of their legacies for the sake of capital income- this is no longer an art form- just another obsolete product that pales in comparison to it's predecessors.

From did make this a difficult game, but players can always modify their ACs to overcome a boss and exploit that boss's weaknesses.

Good or amazing: graphics, UI, soundtrack, sound cues, voice acting, and combat.

Slightly negative: certain builds seem overly strong, to the point where one might be inclined to go with what works over how they want to play.

Probably the best mecha game out there at the moment. It's not a game you'll spend hundreds of hours on, unless you really enjoy the PvP. My 50 hours are solo play only, first playthrough is about 15-20 hours, the story is actually pretty good and you have 3 endings to choose from. All of them are interesting and are nuanced enough that there aren't a "good" or "bad" ending. 

Gameplay wise, this is one of the most enjoyable game in the recent years. It's not that hard, obviously you'll die and retry but deaths aren't as frustrating as Souls game because this game follows missions lasting for about 10 minutes each so you're not losing much by dying. Gameplay is super smooth, with a pretty simple loop meaning everyone will get the hang of it. Lots of customisation options, whether it has a gameplay impact (weapons, mecha frame, secondary weapons) meaning everyone will find their own build they can enjoy. You can roleplay as a gundam if you want, or create your own mecha, lots of paint customization (RGB slider), possibility of adding rust to get a wear down style if you like it, just an impressive range of choice.

Unlike many other games out there, there aren't that many "bad" weapon in PvE. Obviously some of them are absolutely trash in PvP but the AI is much less nimble  than players and most weapons will manage to track properly and deal adequate damage.

This is a game where everyone will find their own enjoyement out of it. Wanna build a light mecha and go rushdown style ? You can. Prefer heavy and long range weaponry? Your choice. Light frame and heavy weapons? You'll be limited in weapon weight but you can have a light frame with two heavy machiguns (but you may have to sacrifice shoulder weapons for that). 

For more "hardcore" players there a ton of things to optimize to get the best build possible, lots of statistics you can account for to maximize everything, and that will come in handy for PvP but you don't have to optimize your builds for PvE only (some bosses might be hard if you don't play attention bewteen the syngergy of your weapons though). 

An excellent game overall. I didn't enjoy the PvP so I stopped after 100% the solo play but I would recommend it, a must if you want to try out the mecha genre.

I love every from software game made except this and I love older Armored Core games as well. 
To put it bluntly, this game sucks.

To be clear, I have tried playing this multiple times years apart to give myself a fresh perspective and my opinion remains the same.

1. Freedom of builds is gone. You are virtually required to build exactly what they want you to build to beat certain fights and bosses.  You will die over and over if you do not and it's generally agreed upon in the community that winning these fights outside of the builds they expect you to use is luck.

2. Because you are "Walter's Dog" the sense of freedom and agency is gone. You are doing missions you must because your handler assigns them to you. You don't feel like a free agent influencing the world as you choose with your actions. This is more of a narrative issue but it doesn't eliminate the feeling of being tightly controlled and funneled in a narrative sense.

3. The build options seem much more restrictive than in previous games.

4. No coop. This is a staple of from software games and is frankly the biggest drawback this game has. I have platinum trophied Sekiro (which is my favorite title in spite of this problem) as well, so it's not that I am dependent on help to beat games like these. 

5. The stagger system is just bad. Damage is not purely avoidable no matter what you do and sometimes you will get hit by a falling mortar shell or something with no ability to dodge it, get stunlocked in place and take even more damage as a result or just outright die.

6. I REVEL in boss difficulty in from software games, but this takes it to an absurd extreme. Bosses are orders of magnitude harder than the rest of the content. To where, I am convinced that if all content was removed and only bosses remained, the game would still require the same amount of time to complete on first playthrough minus maybe 20 minutes of walking.

[h1][b]The First Good Armored Core Game[/b][/h1]

[b]Good[/b]
[list]
	[*]Clear onboarding for its peculiar mechanics.
	[*]Best combat in the entire franchise.
	[*]One of the few well-made mech games in existence.
	[*]No multiplayer achievements.
[/list]
[b]Bad[/b]
[list]
	[*]Still dogged by issues that seem baked into the franchise.
[/list]
[b]Pro-Tips[/b]
[list]
	[*]Pay attention to the tutorials and stat descriptions. Armored Core rewards knowledge and punishes ignorance.
	[*]Don't hold onto parts that aren't working out, you recover 100% of their cost when you sell them.
	[*]New players will find Armored Core's meta is like nothing they've experience before. Don't be afraid to spend an hour or two testing builds and coming to terms with what the game is asking of you.
	[*]Be sure to play the campaign three times.
[/list]
[b]Final Thoughts[/b]      
        As a longtime fan, its pretty neat to see everything from AC2's door hacking to AC5 boost kicks remixed, revamped, and re-imagined for an entry that is both a bold step forward and a culmination of all that has come before. 
	
        Combat is the best it's ever been in the franchise. It's fast-paced somewhat like AC4 but exponentially more controllable due to the advent of an orbital lock-on system which also drastically improves melee combat. ACS Strain, where staggered opponents are open to critical hits, while not new is a definite improvement over Heat and Primal Armor in serving as a way to both elevate and balance combat. These additions result in major improvements to AC and boss battles in particular. The [i]feel[/i] of these battles as you weave through enemy fire, knock your target of balance, and charge in just in time to land a devastating Laser Blade strike that results in their slow-motion death all while [i]never[/i] fumbling with the controls never gets old. The only issue is that most of your opponents will be MTs, foes that are swatted aside with unsatisfying ease. I was often left with a similar sense of yearning I felt while play Sekiro, a desire for more mid-bosses and less two-hit dregs. 

	Flimsy MTs are not the only historic issue that once again rears its head. Certain weapon types continue to be overly utilitarian, with a pair of humble rifles almost never leaving my sides during my S-Rank run. When it comes to the Armored Core itself, flexible mid-weight biped builds still seem to be the "right answer" for single-player and multiplayer is dominated by meta builds. The economy itself continues to feel like a mere thematic conceit with credits being easy to come by and as always devolves into a non-factor around the 1/4 of the way through. 

	Parts and customization continue to be what you expect from an AC game. There are plenty of parts, but it definitely feels like the pointless incrementality of the older entries has been toned down with variants of any individual weapon category thankfully reduced to just two or three and the like. The overall act of customizing your AC to meet either the needs of the mission or your personal preference with said parts is made easier to grasp with the aid of several tutorials that previous entries sorely lacked. Those with sufficient skill will take great pleasure in the revamped emblem and AC painting systems that offer deeper customization than ever.  

	The missions themselves were pleasant if a bit easy due to the aforementioned MTs with a few interesting set-ups like mounting the heavily publicized Strider or taking down a warship fleet in mid-air. You can see the influence of modern FROM in the multiple vantage points from which to surveil enemy packs and optional bosses tucked away in dark corners. The Ace Combat-style radio chatter that pervades the missions gives them a better feel than those from previous entries and enhances their episodic quality. The wider narrative is great by Armored Core standards, which is to say it's acceptable. The audio only approach is impersonal, but the emotional beats are there.  

	While I wish the game provided a little more push-back, AC6 is a joy to play. FROM has whittled away all the counter-intuitiveness if not outright contrarianism of the past, leaving only this gem that I can recommend without reservation.

Armored Core VI was my introduction to the AC franchise and I immediately mourned the time I'd spent without having experience in this awesome, incredible, awesome game series. Perhaps it was for the best, as I hear varying things about how difficult the barrier to entry is in other AC games, but Fires of Rubicon was kind enough to wine and dine me before we settled in for many intense nights together.

From the jump, AC VI warms you up with a simple-to-pilot starter Armored Core, (what the mechs are called), and doesn't ask any more of you than you're comfortable with. After a brief foreplay tutorial, you're given the option to explore and find out what you're really into. The shop is available to you with all sorts of new toys, and you can earn some freebies by going through the more advanced tutorials, so that's immediately where my focus went. I wanted to try anything and everything to find my AC kinks and take on the dom role that I was always meant to play.

After some clumsy fiddling around here and there, I quickly found my erogenous zones to be with the fattest stack of missile launchers on my back, a bazooka-type on one hand, and rapid-fire on the other. I confidently continued to pleasure myself in the face of my enemies, enjoying my high-octane affair with AC VI as it let me have my way with it. Little did I know, our power dynamic was about to shift, as I'd yet to meet Balteus, who would prove to be my first (and second, third, and so on,) death as Rubicon showed me how it gets off. That is to say, I truly felt like we were growing together as a toxic couple and learned to exploit each others weakness through a series of abusive exchanges.

As I continued to play, I was treated to beautiful visions of slaughter, mechanical carnage, and the luminous glow of ruin laying waste to Rubicon and the forces that inhabited it. From Handler Walter sensually whispering sweet nothings in my ear, engaging in a strenuous affair with Ayre, and being unloaded upon by bombardments of artillery and unleashing my load upon others, I would've sworn that my soul was firmly planted on Rubicon at any given moment. The immersion reached was nothing short of orgasmic, and I felt at home inside of my Armored Core.

Truthfully, AC VI allows you to find and express yourself in the truest reflection of the human soul- your awesome mech. The customization is unrivaled and with enough love and attention, you can bring to life the most beautiful and unholy climax in a burst of mechanical conception. There's never a dull dance to be had when you experiment the way I did on Rubicon.

I don't know why this review got so sexual, but I suppose that's just the kind of game Armored Core VI is. It knows what you want better than you do, and it's not going to beat around the bush. It's a tender and fleeting lover, but you know that the nights you spend together are going to be remembered fondly for years to come.

Armored Core6 is solid. I've played through the game multiple times already and unlocked the NG+ content. AC6 uses a mission structure for the campaign and battle arena duels for pvp skirmishes, and the pacing of gameplay is pretty good. So definitely think you would enjoy the mech design, combat and all the eye candy. Sits roughly around a 4/5, because there are a handful of things that could have been handled better, like the music and sound design:

* Even though most of the mechs you come across are cool, some of the "robot themes" fall flat out of the necessity of their use, like the "droning menu screen music." While you're sitting in the menu screen building your mech, which you do quite often, there is this single constant droning hum that makes you want to fall asleep, because there is literally no variation in the baseline. Am not joking about this, it's actually exhausting to listen to, even though it somehow fits "the robot music genre."

* Another place where the robot theme is followed to a fault is the story. There's nothing really noteworthy about the story because in the attempt to make you care about the AI's plight / feeling the need to deliver the narrative with "lethargic, disconnected, robotic voice acting, where the voice actors are reading the dialog and narrative - at you," you wind up not giving a fuck about any of it, skip through it, and just play the game.

* Finally, most of the game's balance makes sense until you reach the end of chapter bosses for sections III, IV and V. Totally get that fromsoft bosses are going to have "different difficulty spikes," but in the case of AC6 we're going from quasi-reality to all-of-a-sudden everything is allowed to jump offscreen / teleport around you like you're trying to catch a fly with a pair of chopsticks. So the fact that these mechanics were just "robotically thrown in" and there were was no sense of progression to these "spikes," made the balance of these boss encounters come off as "forced" in context of the rest of the game. Where other fromsoft games have far more variety and a better sense of progression, rather than just flipping a light switch on and off just because you hit the end of a chapter. The only reason you notice is because it sticks out like a sore thumb. Note: Definitely change your camera sensitivity settings, up to the maximum (10), this will definitely help you with tracking during these encounters.

Besides a handful of basic things, definitely recommend the game. There are a bunch of different weapons and mech parts (boosters, targeting computers, generators, etc) you can combine in different ways to modify the way your mech handles, from chonky beasts to quick agile ninjas with rockets, lasers and gats - so you can keep things straight forward or pull off combat-shotty-laser-sword combos. Definitely worth picking up.

This is a return to form and breath of fresh air for THE best mech combat game ever.
A word of warning, unlike the slow waltzes of Soulslikes, this is an energetic madness through and through. You are not a weakling, but a savage machine, only stopped by overwhelming numbers, pilots of equal skill, or the bosses, who are exceptionally tough.

The main way to advance is to create new builds, one build which excels in one mission is utter crap in another. But apart from that, you can customize the color, wear, decals, and lights of your machine, making it perfectly yours, and even name it! There's fighting in a mech, and then fighting in a mech you perfectly customized!

The voice work is also amazing. You never see a single face in the game, but the talented VAs carry more than enough depth to convey emotion.

You are going to have a great time, and hopefully more is on the horizon!

One of FromSoftware's easier games, but it is just pure destructive fun. Every design decision you make in the garage, you feel in the missions. Sound design is great. Mechs just feel fun to control. You feel like a badass when scything through cannon fodder enemies, but bosses are intimidating like in other FromSoft titles.

The story is short and simple, but like in other FromSoft titles, you have to play it through multiple times to experience it all. The characters you meet are engaging, both as comrades and nemeses. There are a few instances where some characters could be better utilised, but overall I enjoyed my time with them.

I did not engage in the multiplayer, so I have no idea if that is fun. Multiplayer doesn't interest me in this kind of game. I exclusively played singleplayer, and completed the entire game 3 times, to see all 3 endings, and replayed loads of missions to get all achievements. It was super fun finding what parts I liked and didn't like, and trying out different loadouts for specific mission parameters.

If you like the idea of FromSoft games, but think they are a bit too intimidating to play, try this one. It's much easier, it's much less of a commitment, its mission-based designed to be played in short bursts, but it very much feels like a FromSoft game. I wholeheartedly recommend it, 9/10 for me.

Fromsoftware never fails to deliver. Never having played an Armored Core game I went into this blind but this game has brought me into the Armored Core series. The really fast paced movement and fighting was definitely different than the other Fromsoftware games I've played so it took me a while to get used to that (Balteus) but once I did I was having a blast playing.

· Mech customization is on another level you can make your mech look like basically any mech from any show you like and there's even a emblem editor (like old black ops style) where you can merge shapes together to make emblems that you can attach to your mechs.
· Build options in this game let you to go with whatever fighting style you want you could go anywhere between a lightweight build that moves quick and go up close with shotguns and swords to a heavyweight tank with railcannons and rocketlaunchers on your arms and shoulders or even a flying tetrapod build if you prefer being a aerial fighter.
· The story also has good replayability with lovable characters and there's actually new missions and choices that you get to do in NG+ and NG++ which can give you up to 3 different endings with new bosses showing up for each of them. 
· This game was pretty hard for me at first and it'll probably kick your ass over and over but eventually you'll start noticing what certain enemies are weaker too and how to get over some of the defenses they have and I think that makes the challenge much more enjoyable and rewarding.

Armored Core 6 has got to be one of my all-time favourite games. This game genuinely does everything almost perfectly, there is very little that Armored Core 6 does wrong. I asked for Miyazaki to give us a better game than Elden Ring, and boy did he deliver.

Pros:
- Overall fantastic missions. The many missions you will complete throughout the game all feel very fun and have their own unique sets of challenges.
- Tons of customisation options. There are so many different body parts, weapons, and other pieces to put together your perfect AC. And very rarely does a build feel like it can't complete most missions effectively.
- Writing is absolutely phenomenal. The story and themes of this game are extremely captivating and have left a lasting impression honestly stronger than any previous FromSoftware title I have personally played.
- Music is incredible. FromSoftware games always have a phenomenal soundtrack but the soundtrack in this game is just a masterpiece. I only wish the music was louder in some missions so I could hear it better.
- Combat is incredibly satisfying and provides a good challenge while still making you feel like an unstoppable powerhouse.
- Colour and decal customisation for ACs is amazing, the deceptively simple customisation allowed for your AC can take up hours upon hours of playtime.
- This game is filled with memorable characters, even some of the most insignificant characters to the overall plot have incredible personality and characterisation within their dialogue and even the designs of their ACs themselves in some cases.
- Bosses overall are probably some of the most enjoyable fights that I have personally experienced in a FromSoftware game. There are very few bosses that feel cheap, unfair, or unenjoyable to fight.
- Multiple endings as well as a secret ending unlocked through first getting the other 2 endings gives the game tons of replayability despite its somewhat short length and linear mission structure.
- Graphics and visuals are spectacular, this game truly has some of the most stunning visual displays I have seen in media.
- Sound design is extremely crisp and satisfying. Weapons have a real feeling of impact to their sounds, and the sound of your AC's boosters is just so nice to listen to.

Cons:
- I personally felt there could have been a little more choice involved with the game's endings. Other than a couple of choices near the end of the game, there is very little that actually influences which ending you will get.
- Requirements for S-ranking missions are relatively simple but I wish the game would outline them a bit more to the player. Missions should give at least some idea of how to actually S-rank them.
- Lightweight ACs feel like they don't give enough for the sacrifice required. You hardly get much more speed than a medium AC at the cost of being significantly easier to stagger and having much lower health. It would have been nice if lightweights were good at something other than just spamming quick boosts, especially when medium ACs hardly have any more trouble doing so than lightweights.
- The FCS system can be slightly frustrating to deal with at times. It would have been nice to see another way of manually changing your FCS target other than moving your camera, though I suppose the controls might have also become cluttered that way.
- Melee tracking is incredibly inconsistent and sometimes melee attacks will literally whiff despite the target being inside the literal swinging energy blade. I'd like to see a world where the Moonlight and Moonlight but red aren't the only melee weapons that don't reek like diseased feet.
Do you like robots? Play this game. It's hard, you'll blow up a lot, but you'll get better. Don't do the PvP, it's terrible.

A pretty good Mecha game. The weapons are fun for the most part, the part variety allows for a wide array of builds, and the scale of fights can make them really exciting and intense. The colors Fromsoft use here are pretty monotone, but the actual variety and quality of the set pieces makes up for it for the most part. This game has a few downsides, though. Some of the bosses are nauseatingly unfun fights like the Ibis where the enemy doesn't really have any of the limitations imposed on the players besides the stagger bar, and almost feel like they're were designed for an entirely different game with how drastically different they move and attack compared to everything else in the game. Some of the characters really feel more like they are just spouting exposition at the player, rather than actually talking your character. And some scenes that would have a lot more weight if you could at least see them happen entirely off screen, cheapening what could have been tragedies that tug at the player's heart into something inferred happened off screen, with little to no player involvement as they handle what are frankly very uninteresting objectives in comparison to what the player is told is happening. It really feels like this game could have done with at least a few more hours of content to properly explore the cast, or at the very least cutscenes that go more in depth into the characters.
All in all, a very fun mecha game with enjoyable action and customization, but kind of lacking narratively.

I am coming from a decade long of playing From Soft games. These are my impressions so far...

The targeting system in the beginning of the game is disappointing when compared to Elden Ring and especially that it is tied to a stat. Having at least an active targeting system for early bosses would have benefited this game greatly. 

The helicopter boss is easily my least favorite FromSoft starting boss. The whole fight becomes 'fight the camera' more than the actual boss itself. Another lazy way they make this boss 'hard' is that it constantly hides out of bounds of the small battle area, meaning you hit an invisible wall when trying to melee the helicopter. I beat this boss but it wasn't satisfying given that it felt like I 'lucked out', whereas other FromSoft games would punish me for such behavior.  Point is, this should not be a pre-customization boss and it was a bit tone deaf of FromSoft to place him here.

The non-boss content is fun and gives me that ZOE2 feeling, although easy aside from some difficulty spikes in earlier areas. The graphics are gorgeous on my OLED / Nvidia 9080. The music is incredible good and I have already saved the soundtracks on yt music.


So far, I recommend this game, but I think it only really picks up after the first chapter, once the player gets access to mechs that behave responsively in the way they want.

Absolutely not worth the $60 price tag. The amount of content in the game is sorely lacking. My initial play though of the campaign took 19 hours including plenty of garage time and all initial arena combats. It seems they tried to extend this by adding new content to NG+ and NG+2. However, these consist of a handful of added missions and "new perspectives" on old missions, which feel much lazier than the already short main missions, often devolving into eliminating reused enemies in a reused arena. Additionally, 85% of the NG+ campaigns are exactly the same but worse, as the difficulty does not increase in any way and you have access to more items, making them a repetitive, short cakewalk. 

The game feels fun at points, but when missions can take <2 minutes without anything of interest occurring and the entire of the ACTUAL campaign being maybe 15 hours, I would wait for a heavy sale.

I've been playing Armored Core games since the '90s, and I've logged over a thousand hours on AC6, diving deep into both ranked and unranked PvP.

In my opinion, the biggest issues with the game are the hardlock and stagger systems—these mechanics! They don’t belong in an Armored Core game and should never appear in the series again! With these features, the game feels more like a fighting game, akin to Tekken, with 2D combat in 3D graphics.

Let me explain further.

1.) Hardlock:

This provides too much consistency, taking away the player's ability to express skill through unique movements. Once you start using hardlock, your movements become predictable, linear and very similar to others, making the game feel like a 2D fighting game rather than a dynamic mech experience. Why you may ask? There's this invisible tether you have on your target!

Additionally, hardlock is far superior to softlock and manual aiming. While some might argue that softlock offers a slight bonus in lock-on speed. I'd say try using a Zimm shield build with softlock or a kiter with a shield. You'll quickly notice that these builds is only effective because of hardlock. The bonus lock-on speed from softlock is so minimal that it hardly matters; HARDLOCK SIMPLY BURIES THEM ALL!

2.) The stagger system: 

This was NEVER a part of Armored Core, and its introduction has made it the most crucial mechanic in the game?! This further shifts the feel toward a fighting game rather than a true mech simulation. When a player is staggered, they lose control of their AC, limiting their ability to play effectively. The only option is to use an expansion slot, which centralizes PvP around this system.

I could go on about how the FCS functions poorly, the in-game UI lacks intentional design, the game balance is off, and how you can just wiggle your way to victory using a LAMM leg.

TL;DR: The game feels like a tech demo, no matter how you look at it. The campaign is too short, and the multiplayer seems like an afterthought.

Despite these flaws, I still recommend the game because I love Armored Core. BUT BUY IT ONLY ON SALE! NEVER ON FULL PRICE!

TL;DR
If you love AC1-AC3 era, you won't like it. AC4 era, maybe. V an VD maybe.
If you enjoy games like Dark Souls, Sekiro, or pattern games, even schmups, you will most likely enjoy this.

If you're not sure if you want to buy this game, here is how I would view it, since I already bought it. Is this game worth $60? Does it offer a lot of replayability for $60. My honest answer is no. I wouldn't recommend based on that. If you truly want to buy this game, get it on sale. Here's my thoughts.

If you notice the reviews, you can easily tell that the vast majority of them have fairly low hours. If you click further, most users also have no added time in a two weeks span. Use the browse all reviews function, not the front page from the store. This should be a clear indicator of the "value" of the game. There's really not a lot of replayability for this $60 game. It's an easily forgettable game, play once or thrice (if you want all the game endings) and leave it to collect dust.

Speaking of forgettable, there's nothing really memorable to speak of. This is a game that is Armored Core only in name. It has a similar vibe to Dark Souls, Sekiro, Elden Ring, etc., FromSoftware's other titles which brought them to fame. Armored Core didn't bring them to fame, it never appealed to the general audience and it was a niche game within a niche genre. The mech genre was dying, along with this series. The new "Soulslike" mechanics were added to revitalize the series and attract those familiar with the "Soulslike" mechanics. Here's the big thing, Armored Core 6, during an interview with the lead staff, stated it would not be another "Soulslike" game. Except, that's exactly what we ended up getting, so the OG fans will not like this.

The mechanics? The AC AI is specifically scripted to dodge your first 2 shots, ALWAYS, perfectly. After that, you're free to hammer them until a certain amount of time passes when they will perform 2 perfect dodges again. The AI appears intelligent at first, but it's a simple thoughtless pattern.

Patterns? This games revolves around patterns, specifically the bosses. The boss patterns catch majority of players off-guard, however, once you understand there is no intelligence to the bosses except a beautiful and artful display of patterns to distract you, there's nothing special about this game. Ironically, most players get stuck on the Sea Spider boss. I beat it first try and found it far easier than Balteus, mostly because you have better equipment by this time.

In fact, there is a certain youtuber who plays this game expertly without lock-on ability, and can stand still, taking no damage, and only counterattack the boss when they begin their pattern attack (btw they do win). It is truly wild to think this is the style of gameplay Armored Core has chosen to shift to. It doesn't feel like an Armored Core game at all. While V and VD were the most despised games of the series, even I would put them beside the rest of the AC games now, as members that retained the feeling that it is, indeed, an Armored Core game.

Armored Core 6 is a massive departure forcing the stagger guage upon us. The stagger guage is a small attack window where you, or the enemy, is stunned and bonus damage is applied when it is triggered. This essentially boils down to a damage race, with stagger being a large factor, and the game meta will revolve around this. In order to defeat bosses, you absolutely have to take advantage of the stagger guage. While it is possible without using it, it is insanely difficult (I actually tried it, never want to again).

The weapons, they are largely unbalanced and correlate with stagger. Shotguns are the notorious meta for stagger and damage. Very few weapons are actually viable. There is no true long-range gameplay. This game forces you to play up close and personal, hence shotguns being great. Melee is also a big plus, which is not a bad thing, but the implementation of melee is terrible. Melee is locked to a cooldown, so you can't use it to cut down fodder units because of the cooldown. Reserve melee for boss fights, big damage, long cooldown. It's a shame because blading even fodder units in older AC games felt satisfying. There are some weapons you cannot dual wield. Richochet exists, if you're shooting too far away, your bullets effectively do nothing, forcing the close-range gameplay. Gatling guns are amazing up close as well, can't say the same for the other MGs and rifles, they just don't do enough damage to effectively stagger an enemy or pummel them by sheer force. Handguns, no reason to use them when better options exist. At least in the older games, they were viable, in AC6, absolutely not.

While movement improved somewhat, it's super janky, it doesn't feel very mechanical. It just feels like a person cosplaying as a robot and you'll notice it. There's a level of twitchiness when you're turning the character around, it's akin to just a normal humanoid RPG game. The camera can be severely awful at times. On that note, there is Hard-Lock, Soft-Lock, and No-Lock. Hard-lock, you never lose your target. Soft-lock is similar to the OG lock style, just a round lock-box instead. No-Lock, self-explanatary.

Customization is nowhere near on the same level as older games, one of the greatest features of Armored Core that earned it praise for years since its first release. Parts are reduced to a tiny fraction of the older games. For a game that is next-gen, it is severely lacking. Many things were culled to simplify for the new audience. The names and designs are underwhelming. They did try to do as many nolstagic throwbacks though. Those nolstagic gimmicks do not substitue for good bones of an Armored Core game, which this game doesn't have. It only has the skin of it. Though it's supposed to be a reboot, again, I would rather play the first Armored Core game over this.

Oh, but Rusty and the rest. Rusty is barely memorable, though I will attribute him being similar to Solo Wing Pixy. I liked Pixy better than Rusty. Ayre, not memorable, she is akin to Cortana from Halo, a voice talking in your head that goes crazy. Cortana was better. Joshua O'Brien, White Glint (even just 1 mission at Line Ark) are far more memorable, even Apple Boy. Even MTs are more memorable, like OWL, Big White, Super Scimitar, Devastator, and I could go on. Point is, the cast in Armored Core 6 is forgettable.

They tried really hard for a nolstagic trip while also catering to a new audience, yet ultimately didn't succeed in what made Armored Core amazing. Last Raven is the last true Armored Core game, and it's pretty advanced with part destructability and tuning. It's followed closely by AC4, FA, and lagging far behind is V and VD. I'd rather grind through Last Raven and all 6 endings all over again any day over this.

I want to like this game, but there are 100 little frustrations that add up to this feeling like a slapdash, unpolished experience. Like I don't even dislike the game, but I cannot actually recommend it. I'll probably even try to finish it. I'm a huge fan of From Software games, but this is not really doing it for me the way the Soulsborne games do.

Like another example is the way that input queues work. In Elden Ring, if I press a button it queues that and does what I pressed. Sometimes that gets me killed--like if I accidentally heal when I meant to dodge. But Armored Core 6 doesn't seem to queue inputs. So I'll die frustrated knowing that I pushed the button I intended, but the game didn't respond. I'd rather die because the game queued my inputs and my inputs were stupid than not queue my inputs and I die because of that.
Some things are poorly implemented but its definitely an armored core game... to the core.

Take your time, Fromsoft likes throwing difficulty curves at you so try to learn the enemies and you can always change your build to suit the opponent.

Some mods have come out for the game but it can be tricky setting it up properly without getting your account banned from the fromsoft servers so just keep that in mind.

Seriously, From Soft has been a letdown with both the ER DLC and this (just got around to playing it). 

I just finished the game and here is my take.

First, it is incredibly short. Most missions will take you 20 minutes to do. On several of the missions, I was like 'thats it???'

Second, movement/combat - its really annoying. The best way I can put it is that you're an ice skater with a jetpack. You move in a linear direction and sometimes it is nearly impossible to evade attacks.

Third, lack of challenge - throughout the entire game I was just smoking everything (after the first boss struggles b/c I was learning the controls/concept). Bosses, 'S' ranked arena enemies, killing them all in the first go. 

The second to last boss posed the biggest threat. Why? Not because the attacks - the patterns were quite simple. No, it was because I kept running out of ammo to fight. Was it my aim? Possibly, so I tried to wait until my stupid robot was locked on with the red circle. Still ran out of ammo.

Nothing is more frustrating to have a boss beat in an action style shooter only to be short on ammo. Totally flawed. Sure, you could argue the logic was to have you experiment with builds - which I did. But, in a gun mech shooter, boss battles should come with enough ammo regardless of what build you use without requiring 99% accuracy.

Oh, and in that particular battle, the lock on feature stopped functioning entirely. I tried many, many times to get it to work. I had to restart the game. 

Fifth, game length. Incredibly short. I have 17 hours on record and 2 of those were spent trying not to run out of ammo.

Sixth, atmosphere/world. Nothing special at all. I could have likely envisioned something more creative. I'm not flattering myself - if snowy mountains, boring caves that look the exact same and maps used multiple times for different levels is your thing, then go for it.

This game sucks and is laughable at a $60 price tag. From Soft is acting like they can just throw out crappy short games/content like the ER DLC. 

Don't get mad at me if you love From Soft and the AC series. I really enjoyed ER and Dark Souls and felt those were well worth the money, but this felt like a crappy movie sequel without any substance or thought. The only thing that kept me going was the voice acting of Ayre.

Modern take with an old school feel.

Reminiscent of N64 titles I played as a kid like Star Wars: Rogue Squadron, or Star Fox 64. 

Without spoiling too much, the game also has a lot of replay-ability, or to put it more accurately rather great New Game+ mode system that opens up new content, story, and missions.

Can't say good how the state of the game is at the time of this review, however, at launch the game did have some weapon balancing issues, with shotguns being overpowered, especially in PVP. But the devs have been balancing it since, from what I hear. 

 I can't compare it to previous instalments as it's my first AC game, but I love the skill ceiling the game has. You ever replay a mission in a game you sucked at the first time around, but come back to on a 2nd playthrough? Only to dominate that mission the 2nd time around using the same gear, to to realise it WAS a "skill issue" the first time around, and to realise how much you've improved.

Will definitely buy the next instalment if they buy more.

Only complaint is that even though it's artistically impressive, it's not graphically impressive. They are using a ageing game engine, they seem to be unwilling to give up. It runs far better than Elden Ring (their other title using the same engine), with less stutters, and a higher frame limit of 120FPS, instead of 60. No GPU shader compilation stutter like Elden Ring had.

While Mecha was never quite the japanese-related import that I became autistically obsessed with for most of my life, playing this game has re-awakened my tacit appreciation for the mecha genre that I have had since boyhood. While not at all the same mechanically, I get the same thrill playing this game as I did playing Robot Alchemic drive back on the PS2. Its just similar enough for a souls-like fan for me to enjoy, but so much more that its a new and fresh gameplay experience for me. Oh, and fromsoftware's mastery of artistic design + mecha is overkill. These have to be the coolest looking mechs ive seen in a long time. So much so that I actually love the high degree of customization, despite normally disliking this feature in other games because I feel like its inclusion is merely a complex frivolity. Thats not the case in this game. In AC6 i want to make all the coolest looking mecha color combos. While I probably wont go as far as to check out the earlier Armored core titles once I finish this game, I'm glad to have been given such an awesome mecha action experience.

As my first introduction to Armored Core, Fires of Rubicon was the equivalent of Sekiro with mecha fights, the difficulty curve is really steep, but heavily rewarding. Needless to say this isn't exactly a deflecting based game like Sekiro, but just like Sekiro, it teaches you everything through gameplay alone, in a way, it can be played as a rythm game, because if you try to fire everything at once, chances are, you miss all shots because you didn't wait for the right moment to retaliate.

From a vast variety of builds, weapons and playstyles, Up until the endgame of my first NG route I was on a mildly "middle weight" build that punished me more than I wanted to, and while it would have been hilarious to tank enemies with a heavy build, nothing beats destroying your opponents with huge speed and effective "gotcha" weapons.

A recurring theme for my replaythroughs of NG+ and NG++, is that I've learned how to play the game after I beat it once, you think you've learned the basics, but there's even more things that I either underappreciated, underrated or overlooked because I thought they were not as effective, turns out I was wrong, and I'm glad I was.

The humbling experience of adjusting your build to the vast arsenal at your disposal made me enjoy the game a lot, and defeating strong foes never ever felt so satisfying to destroy them just as quickly as they used to destroy me. Gameplay loop is definitely satisfying, and never gets old. This is exactly how you create masterclass gameplay that feels too responsive to your needs (unless you have massive skill issue like I had several times lol)

Here's hoping FS makes a DLC, because damn this game piqued my interest in the franchise.

Amazing game!

If you remotely love the mecha genre this game is for you. Fast paced action set in a universe that's believable and interesting. If you've played the dark souls series this game will feel somewhat familiar. The ability to keep going after you died and redesign your Armored Core after failing to fine tune it for the mission is forgiving enough but not tipping over in terms of integrity of difficulty. This game will kick your ass over and over and over again till you figure out how to deal with certain situations with the right build. Bosses are unique and have different weaknesses to exploit with different ways to go about beating them. Gliding around beating mobs make you feel like a cold blooded bad ass and feels so smooth its like a hot knife cutting through butter. Not to mention the more efficient you get the higher the score you get. Speed, ammo, how many mobs you kill, and how much health you lost are apart of getting a high score so there is a challenge in that. The different builds you can make also create a uniqueness to how you want to play. Tank with big guns? Small and agile? All rounder? or a frankenstien of an AC? You can do it all. You have absolute freedom in how you build you Armored Core and that's fun in itself. Not to mention there are parts to collect and data to collect in almost every mission to unlock even more parts. There are also different missions with decisions that alter your path so that adds replayability considering there is NG and NG+ which also lets you keep the parts you've acquired. Great game all in all, for a 60 dollar game with no major dlcs there are a bunch of hours to sink in 1000% worth it. You won't regret it if you like a challenge.

Some online reviewers on places like youtube may say that this game lacks a story, they are wrong, it has an amazing story which is just told in an unorthodox way. Via radio and comms channels that characters will use during missions that you will have to pay attention to in order to understand what is going on. There are 3 endings to this game with the 3rd ending being unlocked on your 3rd playthrough of the game. Trust me, each playthrough is worth it, even if you have finished the game once, there is new things the game introduces to you on your 2nd and 3rd playthroughs that have been locked away from you on your first playthrough, so the game still contains a few surprises up its sleeve with new missions and events until you get that 3rd ending which is considered the true ending. So you haven't fully completed the game until you have gotten that 3rd ending and earned the stargazer achievement. This is an amazing game and I'll be looking forward to seeing new armored core games in the future from FromSoftware
