[b]Armored Core: The Problem Of Flow™[/b]
[i]I will be brief 621. I am gonna tell you why despite being such an unique game, Armored Core has a serious flow problem.[/i]

So yes, Armored Core has a serious flow problem which breaks the fun of the game all the time for me. And it is not just because of the mission based progress in the game. I played Ace Combat 6 too, it is also a mission based game. You're jumping in and out of missions that last mostly 20 to 30 minutes. And i had this problem in Ace Combat too but not like this. 

Ace Combat 6's missions were fulfilling and when you finish a mission you felt tired so it was nice to stop and relax, buy some upgrades to your aircraft for the next mission. Plus, it's story-telling were better than Armored Core 6. Even in missions there were some interesting interactions between characters, dialogues which you had to listen, you were also given a new quest or new goal in a mission and you had to listen to them because it didnt give you those within the hud or markers in the map/game. So you were not just using a plane and shooting enemies, you had to pay attention to the dialogues to finish the missions. Its missions were engaging and multilayered in this matter. Nice combat + storytelling + extra instructions/directives in missions that require attention from player = fulfilling/satisfying missions. A game that demands your full attention while playing and tires you out. So meta-game was also needed to relax, to take a break and to think about aircraft upgrades. 

Armored Core 6 on the other hand, besides having great and difficult (i cant easily say ''satisfying'', i will get to that) combat, has no other engaging features or captivating storytelling in its missions. You are a mercenary going to missions to missions and finishing them. Surely, there's a story but its not connected like Ace Combat 6. Since its written by Fromsoftware, there's no simple story being told directly with every detail. So it can't make you go for the next mission directly to learn the more of the story. That's a problem but it is not a game about story anyway. It is about gameplay. 

Gameplay also suffers from missions designs. Some missions are really short and you just kill bunch of mechas and than they end. Some of them is last enough (The longest one probably doesn't last more than 15 minutes tho.) but still somehow they too are not satisfying like Ace Combat's missions. They are very linear, you follow the signs in the map, sometimes collect somethings, mostly kill some enemies and beat the boss fights, thats it. They are too linear and *unseasoned* that cant satisfy you. Since it is not a boss rush game (or maybe it is?), it must have more than boss fights. 

Unseasoned: There's no engaging interactions or dialogues since you are alone in the missions. You can still finish them even if you don't listen to people talking in your ear. Meaning, you can do them just by following signs in the game. (Maps are already limited in many ways, why the need for markers, i dont understand.) You randomly shoot everything you see and easily reach to the boss fight most of the time. And even boss fights are not that satisfying. Yes they are difficult but with the right build, fights end really fast for the good or bad. Somehow it can not provide that satisfaction from other Fromsoft games' boss fights. 

[b]So all we have left are these: Great combat - no captivating storytelling - no multilayered / unseasoned mission designs - no extra directives in missions - lots of limitations in maps - no extra things to pay attention - not much satisfying boss fights (Sorry but i feel this way) = unappealing missions = flow problem / a period of time of thinking about whether or not to take on the next mission + maybe taking a break so long that when you re-enter the game, you propably forgot the controls / how to play. [/b]

Combat is great. And it is exceptionally good and so deep and wide on making a mecha build. It is distinguished in those matters. Still havent tried the PVP, but i think it is a blast too. (I watched a lot of videos on it. All were great.) But the flow problem is solid. And i felt like we should talk about this. So wrote this. 

Btw, the soundtrack is fabulous thanks to Kota Hoshino.

This game is an incredible experience, with a gripping story that will shatter you emotionally, having multiple endings that will each leave you wanting for more, somehow managing to break your heart without showing a single face even once.

Armored core VI plays like a movie and is the perfect combination between a massive power trip and roleplaying as the victim, with your ass getting handed back to you more often than not. With insane customization options for your mech, custom paint jobs, a complex decal maker and hundreds of different weapons and parts, you’ll spend more time recreating your favourite anime mechs in the garage than inside of actual missions. If you’ve ever wanted to play barbie’s dress up with war crimes, this game is definitely for you.

Despite looking really confusing at first, all the small mechanics in the game are masterfully intertwined and fall into place as you climb up to the ever-rising skill ceiling as new weapons, abilities and parts are introduced. If you manage to get through the journalist filter on the first mission, you’ll be fine.

Overall, armored core VI is insanely good, and I recommend it a LOT to anybody that’s even slightly interested in it. In no time you’ll be hooked on its satisfying and rewarding gameplay loop, with weapons feeling incredibly responsive and every death feeling fair or at the very least, your fault. Whenever you get tired of getting your ass beat in the story, you can choose to play some multiplayer and get your ass handed to you by some broken meta build.

If you're new to mech games in general I'd recommend waiting for a sale, but this is another great Armored Core (AC) installment. The combat is basically ultra-fast paced dark souls in mech suits with more buttons, flight, and dashing instead of rolling. It's not open world so you'll be going back to the garage between missions (which makes sense for how the story / game is structured). I love that they've added plenty of closeup & short cutscenes of your custom mech throughout the game, it really added a lot to the visual appeal of the game and shows off how much love the design / artwork teams put into this title.

I've noticed a lot more emphasis on melee if the tutorial boss is anything to go by. I've made it to the start of Chapter 2 at this point. The tutorial boss is by far the hardest thing I fought outside of the last boss in Chapter 1, and I probably would have had an easier time with that if I'd adjusted my weapons. Both bosses seem to require an "up close and personal" touch, but the tutorial boss took me 5 or 6 attempts since my medium/close preference didn't match with the close & aggressive style needed to take it out. 

One of the only frustrating aspects to the AC series is the lack of explanation for abbreviations... This can make some things confusing if you're new to AC, or maybe if it has been a while. For instance they say "MT", "forces", "units", etc. without much explanation on what the difference is. You will quickly learn that "MT" is going to be something like an AC but a lot weaker but unless you use google there's no way you'll know it means "Muscle Tracer" and even then it doesn't really do much to explain anything unless you read a wiki article.

If it's your first armored core game like it was for me, get it on sale. It's a game that gleefully dances the line between being insanely fun and also being easily the worst PVE balanced game fromsoft has released in the last decade. People who have any amount of time in the game can agree that there is a serious issue with weapon balance while going through the missions. Chapter bosses aren't really memorable (except the 3rd), most are just gear checks to see if you have the right weapons and legs equipped for them and they're only really hard in the first run since after beating them you usually get a new weapon in the shop that memes on the boss you just struggled with and are bad in the other rest of the game.

The game pretty desperately needed a second tutorial after the first mission for AC building since that's a surprisingly in depth system that if you don't have a solid grasp on will bite you in the ass very quickly unless you're using the god weapons.

The new game+ is neat but I won't talk about it because I don't want to spoil it.

It's a game that would have massively benefited from having a free demo of the first 1-3 missions to see if it was going to be something I'd enjoy. It's alright, some aspects of the design are deeply flawed in my opinion and if I knew that going in I'd have waited for a sale, though I personally wouldn't recommend this game to a regular gamer who doesn't know what they're getting into.  The game is a lot to handle and  it won't hesitate to stomp you into the ground  for hours on a single boss and make you spend 40 minutes customising your AC just to have you change your entire build to suite the mission you just failed.

If I had to compare it to anything, the game is like a pond in terms of depth. The difficulty is surface level and deeply unsatisfying most of the time with few bosses ever requiring knowledge past the surface of "Build a weapon with good stagger and mash off reload." The story is interesting, it has some good depth and requires a few runs to fully get with the branching missions. It's not elden ring deep, but it doesn't have to be and it's good for what it is. For as much depth as I said AC building had earlier, it's just as easy to brute force your way through the entire game in trial and error like old arcade games. My first run of the game was at release with no idea what the meta was developing, but after dying to the chapter 2 boss a few times and switching my weapons frequently, I found that dual shotguns were strong and then never switched off of them for the entire rest of my first run and NG+ despite my AC build not actually even being good.

There's depth here, but it rarely ever goes beyond the surface. You can purpose build your AC to be the best at using dual miniguns with perfect accuracy within 120 meters and blitz through missions with an incredibly intricate build where every stat means something, or you can just throw together an AC that looks cool and as long as you're using 1 of the 7 best weapons in the game you can just walk through everything anyway despite all your stats being terrible because the weapon balance is just that lopsided.

It's hard to identify anything I like about this game.

Most importantly, combat doesn't feel good.

You have a dodge, but not i-frames. You have shield options, but not perfect parry. Enemy weapons are often rapid fire, or scatter shot. Taken all together this means that you are always getting hit _a little bit_. Using dodges and movement correctly will reduce how much you get hit, but never make you completely untouchable. This results in a feeling that there is no visceral feedback for playing well.

In other games with dodging and/or parry mechanics, it "feels" very different to avoid an attack correctly vs to fail. But in this game, it always feels the same. You get hit a bit. Always.

That's all about receiving damage, but what about giving damage? Well every weapon feels about the same. There's a few different classes of weapon: rapid fire, single shot, explosive etc. but at the end of the day they all amount to "fling hit boxes at the enemy". None of it feels _meaningfully_ different. 

What about build versatility? This really ought to be a strong point for the game, but it just isn't. While there are very many different components you can buy and stick together, you have to buy every individual piece, and the game is very stingey with money. In order to actually buy enough stuff to have any versatility you'll need to grind out old missions. Repeating the exact same level over and over again, just so that maybe you can buy a gun that has a marginally different ideal range.

Plot? No idea. This is classic From Software. Huge amounts of vague text hinting at something, but never an indication why I, the player, should care. Random faction is doing random thing against some other random faction. OK, so what? When all the world building is told in this deliberately opaque way, I'm never given a reason to invest in anything or anyone emotionally.

What about the maps and environments? I sure hope you like grey. Every building is grey. It's always snowy. There are lots of different maps, but they all look the same.

I have fully finished the game and aquired all achievements. If you value experience take of my review what you will. This is one of few mech games I have played start-to-finish. The others were the old Mechassault series for the original Xbox, and Mecha Knights: Knightmare. I am picky with my mech games. Gundam has not cut it for me for reasons I'll get into briefly. Neither has the new Mechwarrior although it had potential. This is one that does near everything right. I generally disdain PVP-based gameplay so my review lacks any input on that front. The negatives are a shorter list so i'll start with those.

[h2] NEGATIVES [/h2]
- [u] MOBILITY: [/u] Gravity and Direction of travel should not suddenly cease existing if you get stunned in mid-air, or mid boost. This is a foolish thing. If your mech is paralyzed in every way (including propulsion!), you should fall; or at least keep going in the direction you were moving when stunned. Conservation of momentum is a thing, and I never got over the frustration of this.
     - I understand the reasoning for the stun mechanic. I do think that avoiding stun in general has made me a better pilot, but it makes for frustrating tactical decisions when myself or an enemy suddenly STOPS MOVING. The mechanic is supposed to be jarring. It is. A bit too much. It is overall a fun mechanic though... [i] QUICK, QUICK, SLOW... [/i]

-[u] RANGE: [/u] I do wish longer range engagements were more viable. Most levels are designed to not need or benefit from it, however I do wish that some weapons had a longer range before deflecting. (Stun needles, long rifles, explosives, etc. Kinetic or otherwise.) Aiming in general is fine, I have no desire for scopes to be included. Range would just make manual aiming more fun and applicable in some missions. Another method of engagement, or flair for your fighting style.

- [u] PARTS: [/u] It would be nice to get all the parts of the PCA mechs and the Institute relics,  or at least the final boss''s mech. More heads are sorely needed. The expressions the faces or light bars really sell some body-head combos. Proportions on some parts seem off bipedal legs specifically. Some are just ugly... even when part of their own set. I like making different mechs with varying "personalities". Some parts just don't have a "fit". Perhaps it is the extreme proportion change between the torso and legs that throws me, or perhaps the lack of knees. Not sure... not analyzed enough to give better detail.

- [u] GAMEPLAY: [/U] every once in a while it feels as though my input is denied. not always in bossfights, but it primarily occurs during flight. Sometimes it takes more than one click of a key to fire a weapon. The most common occurence is trying to fly after being drained of boost. I will assault boost or hover somewhere, knowing I wont make it in one go. I run out of boost (expected...), but then upon partial recharge, I will be unable to re-hover until the gauge is fully refilled.
     -Note: It does not happen enough to ruin enjoyment of the game. Don't let this point dissuade you from purchase. This is rare enough that may never happen to most, but is often enough to break immersion when it happens. This seems to be more common during extended play-sessions, & I do play on a laptop that gets hot. However, my machine usually creates graphical issues when overheated, not functional ones. The machine also force-updated itself to Windows 11 so make of this what you will. (Dell Alienware, lots of problems ever since, but not while gaming.)

[h2] POSITIVES [/h2]

Where do I begin? I fear this game is like Baldur's Gate 3 in that my expectations may not allow room for a lower quality experience.

- [u]  GAMEPLAY: [/u]  Controls are tight. Impact is delicious, controller or not. I use mouse & keyboard b/c it is faster, & more efficient to hit flat, low-profile keys than to pull triggers. Movement in each AC feels natural for its build. Punches are punishing, walking gaits are varied and interesting. The tank is a gutteral bohemoth, while the "wheelchair" legs feel like the rollercoaster is about to fly off the rails. The medium-weight reverse-joints add a wonderfully predatory sway to instill terror in lowly MT's. Hitting with the Pilebunker or Laser Lance is extremely satisfying. The gun recoil on some rifles and explosives make you feel like a Badass Mech-Rambo or Schwartzenegger. 

- [u] OPTIONS: [/u] The weapons and capabilities are fantastic! You can fly daintily and shit hellfire, be a gliding steel wall, a wheeled whacko with an unhealthy addiction to lead. You could be part of a royal guard, or the Royalty itself. Sometimes I decide to "fly pretty good for a brick..." The parts options and room for viability is fantastic. Variability is one thing sorely lacking in the Gundam department. The paint and decal functions are the butter to my bread, Makes me feel like a manufacturer of these machines as well as an expert pilot. Some more symmetrical variants of some heads would be nice.

- [u[ STORY: [/u] There are enough layers to what's going on to feel like you are actually immersed in the universe, but not so many that you lose track of what's going on. The characters are all varied and interesting. Even though you only hear their voice, they end up mattering to you in a way. No sappy sob stories, but there is emotional weight as you go through your missions with "friends" on the line. The story is straightforward enough until the third ending. Thought provoking, as morality is grey all the way. Finding & reading all the logs brings interesting depth, as do Allmind's "logs" on the arena contestants. 


[h2] NEUTRALS & NITPICKS [/h2]

- [u] MUSIC: [/u] I am not really sure what to make of others' intense enjoyment of this. I like the intro music. but for the most part, the music fades into the background during gameplay. It is unobtrusive. I prefer it this way, as the focus is on the voices. Replaying missions also becomes less tedious...


- [u] AC Test: [/u] Would be cool to able to face more types of enemies here. (Bosses included)

Buy it. Love it. Become Masochistic... You wont regret.

To preface this, I should state that I have played and enjoyed all of Fromsoft's Souls titles, but I had not touched Armored Core until this game. Please keep in mind that I am heavily biased towards Soulslike gameplay, and elements of this game that I found satisfying may be unsatisfying to fans of older AC titles and vice versa. Also, I've barely touched PVP so I can't comment on it.

With that being said, this is one of the greatest games ever made.

There are very few games that I would call universally fantastic, but this is one of them. I have so few problems with this game, and said issues are so minor that they're easily superseded by the numerous positives:

(The following are in order of personal importance to me; most important to least important.)

GAMEPLAY: The core gameplay of this game is probably the most fun I've ever experienced. I have completed every mission at least 10  times, but I still find myself opening the game and jumping in a mission just to experience the near-perfect combat. I know stagger has been a somewhat contentious mechanic, but I personally love it. Hearing the ever-satisfying ACS Overload noise and deleting a significant portion of the enemy's health bar will never not be addicting to me. Even the simple act of moving around manages to be fun, so the brief moments of travel between mechanical murder are never dull.

CUSTOMIZATION: This isn't just referring to the AC and Emblem customization options, which are both huge pluses for fashion addicts like me, but also build variety. I originally thought I would make one build, then stick with it and ignore most other options. However, unlike most of the Souls games, I actually felt encouraged and rewarded for switching up my build and playstyle when appropriate. The fact that you can sell back parts for 100% of their value means there is essentially zero reason not to experiment, and the vast majority of parts are viable in at least one context. I have 14 builds saved, all of which are fairly distinct from each other, and have managed to beat the final boss using all of them. Some are much more difficult to use than others, but the fact that a slightly above average (if we're being generous) player like myself was able to do such a thing speaks to the fact that almost any build can be viable.

MUSIC: I didn't expect this game's music to be able to match up to Souls music, which, for me personally, it did not. However, this game still has a fantastic soundtrack, and I implore everyone who plays it to pump the music slider up to 10. Most of the level soundtracks lean more towards ambiance, and you probably won't notice them unless you're actively paying attention to them. The boss soundtracks, on the other hand, are absolutely worth a listen. Fromsoft has always been fantastic when it comes to boss music, and this game is no exception.

NARRATIVE: I thought this game would just be Rock'em Sock'em Robots, but I was surprised by how well written it was. The storytelling is much more direct than it is in the Souls games, but it didn't suffer as a result like I thought it would. Most of the characters don't have an incredible amount of depth (With some exceptions that I can't explain because spoilers) but they make up for it by having eccentric personalities and aptly written dialogue. The overarching plot is similar, being relatively simple while having enough cool and compelling moments to remain interesting.

PRESENTATION: This game's art style is brilliant. The corporate machines, wrecked landscapes, and other places I can't spoil never failed to captivate me and make me feel immersed while I shoot people in the face with a shotgun the length of a bus.

All of these positives are present throughout nearly the entire game. There are maybe two missions that I don't enjoy, and even then I can understand their purpose. Now, for my few cons:

REPLAY VALUE: This doesn't apply to me, as I will never tire of playing random missions and making new builds just for the fun of it, but if that isn't enough to keep your interest, the game doesn't have much to do after your first four playthroughs aside from PVP. You're not rewarded in any way for playing beyond this point, as once you've gotten all the achievements, grabbed all the collectibles, and bought every part, there's nothing to work towards. COAM is completely worthless once you buy everything, so your money counter will climb into the hundreds of millions, only to never be used for anything. I don't really care about this since the gameplay is amazing enough for me to keep playing, but don't expect more than 50-60 hours out of the game if you aren't addicted like me.

S-RANKS: Replaying missions will allow you to be graded on your performance, and one of the achievements requires you to get an S-Rank on every mission. The problem is that the game gives you very little info on how to get S-Ranks beyond "Go fast and don't screw up." A couple missions require you to kill a certain enemy or do a certain thing you wouldn't normally do to get an S-Rank, meaning you can perform excellently on a mission and not get the S-Rank because of something the game didn't tell you about. In fairness, the previously quoted summary does apply to the vast majority of missions, but the few that it didn't were irritating to deal with.

As previously mentioned, these cons are incredibly minor in comparison to the outstanding positives, and they may not even be an issue for some.

In short, if you enjoy fast-paced action and think big robots are cool, please buy Armored Core 6. I cannot overstate how much enjoyment this game has brought me and will likely continue to bring me. If this review gets anyone else addicted to funny robot game, I will die a happy man.

Having never played any Armored Core game before this, I can’t speak to its place in the series. I have put several hundred hours into various Souls games and Elden Ring, Fromsofts other releases you might have heard of. Armored Core 6 shares the bossfight DNA from these fantasy games, as well as the deep character (mech) customization, all wrapped in a Japanese leaning mech style. 

Think of a mech character concept, and you can probably build an approximation of it in AC6. Sword swinging, fast dashing melee character? High-flying hover drone with heavy weapons? Gundam replica with laser weaponry? It can all be done in AC to suit whatever playstyle you like. Speed is a huge part of the mech style here though - if you’re into slow moving, ponderous titans from say Warhammer 40k, that’s not really possible given the speed of combat.

The boss battles are the highlight here, and learning a boss fight is much like learning a Souls boss. Lots of trial and error to learn how to avoid damage, while searching for windows to deal your own. The fights feel faster paced at first, but your own mech is also faster, so after a few hours this becomes a seamless part of the experience. The Bo’s music is very well done, and adds a lot to the setting and heart pounding boss battles - the final boss of chapter 1, Balteus, and his track “Contact with you” is what sold me on the game, I get goosebumps thinking about those first 30 attempts and how fun, challenging and rewarding they were. 

I do wish the levels and worlds in between boss fights were a little more fleshed out. There is a little bit of exploration or choice within the levels, somewhat dictated by the type of mech you’ve built and it’s movement abilities, but levels are pretty linear for the most part. This would be fine except that the rooms can feel trivial at times, with little challenge until you reach a named boss enemy or mini boss. 

I only tried a little bit of the PvP near launch. Much like Souls PvP it’s extremely difficult, with range control, ammo/cooldown management, and fast reactions being the main draws. It has a small but dedicated player base, but it will take some serious dedication and practice to get competitive at this point in the games life cycle. There are 3v3 team modes, but my sense is the 1v1 duels are what hardcore players play the most. 

Overall this is an easy recommendation for fans of Souls games who are looking for something more sci-fi. It’s different enough to feel fresh but at its CORE shares DNA with Fromsofts bread and butter titles.

Not for the faint of heart. Death is a fact of life. Damage is the cost of operation.

True to FromSoft games, skill requirement of this game is extremely high. Newcomers will face a super boss that hits like a truck in the very first mission using inescapable pre-determined equipment. Use this as a gate to make decisions, if you can't beat the first boss in two hours, the game might not be fore you. It's not too late to refund, but you should use everything you learn in that very first mission against this boss. Be aggressive. You have all the tools you need. Watch the boss. Watch your own resources. Range is not your only option. Remember that big damage comes with a big gamble.

This game is not an easy game, and it makes a very questionable decision of putting a major road block in THE VERY PROLOGUE. It is a heavy action game while at the same time not brainless. Every decision you make, every part you select makes an incremental impact that culminates into your final mech's, your Armored Core's, performance. Each part has stats, superficial shown at first and in-depth shown when you dig, all transparently displayed. All stats affect how well your Armored Core performs in each regard. While games like Dark Souls allow you to compensate all the stats you lack with skills and extreme reflexes, Armored Core will hit you with reality. There is no such thing as invincibility frames. If your mech is too heavy with armor, and your booster is not strong enough to support your heavy weight, your dash will be too short to get you out of anything. You won't be able to jump to reach enemies high up. If you mech is too light, you will have to brace harder when firing big weapons. If your legs or arms are too scrawny, you won't be able to support your load. Heavy explosives come with large weight. Powerful energy weapons come with hefty energy cost. Think carefully before you bring each part into a mission. Use the right tool for the job. The majority of the time, change equipment will get you through everything.

I've always maintained that tere aren't enough MECHA games.... not in the sense that I think most people imagine them - pilot some huge hunk of metal and blast/punch your way through relentless boom boom combat. For some reason, all mecha games seem to be some sort of turn based/4x strategy and economy simulators. I'm thinking of battletech, into the breach and others. Those games are great, but they're not great because mecha. They're just well designed strategy with mecha theme. However, When I think of GIANT ROBOTS I generally don't immediately think of chess, or how much each arm part costs FIRST. This is what AC6 gets right (as someone new to AC series... yes, I know it's 'been here all along' but it seems previous entries you had to surgically attach extra appendages to succeed) ...In AC6 the combat is real time, fast, satisfying and has the weight of all that souls-borne 'tough-but-fair' combat design experience that makes encounters REWARDING and suitably CRUNCHY. Then, sure, afterwards I'll weigh how much $$ to spend on a new bazooka. Great! Not to hate on strategy or 4x, but it just seems to make so much more sense to me that GIANT ROBOTS BLASTING is first, economy/strategy/deeplore/optimization is second.

Well this is an armored core game alright, you can build your big mech, customize it, do this and that and it all works well. Where the game falls flat, though, is in the fun department as obviously what From Software sees as fun is throwing all kind of overpowered enemies at you and see what sticks. 

This would be fine in a dark souls game where you have big open maps, can plan your encounters in advance but it totally does not work here in this instanced 5 min run type a thing game. You get your big shiny mech, take it on a mission, kill trash for 2 minutes, encounter a boss kill it and then rinse and repeat. The whole game is just that - bunch of unconnected instances where you dip in do whatever is necessary in increasingly unfair environment and dip out, then do it again and again. Fun? Nah, not to me this shit isn't fun.

Looking at the achievements it starts strong 99% people beat the first mission and then it steadily drops off to have about 35% of people beating the whole game, of course, looks like im not the only one not having fun here. 

There is also an arena mode and it's cool and all but meh its more of those 5 min things to do in this game, go out there try your mech and do it again with the next guy.

Thinking about it, there is also story but somewhere in 3rd chapter i just started skipping it, as it's bunch of nonsense about coral, about some bitch living in your head AYRE which you get after defeating some missile boat boss. It's all nonsense. 

The core is there but the fun is not, literally a shiny turd is what this game is. Damn shame, could have been something good.

Miyazaki's done it again 😁

10/10 character customization

10/10 weapon variety

The story and lore are cool but hard to follow. They provide more dialogue and character interaction than other FromSoft games, though.

Multiple routes and endings make repeat playthroughs worthwhile, with only a few missions being stupidly hard unless you have the right gear.

Combat is fun but can be a button-mash fest as you spam all weapons constantly against certain types of enemies, without much thought to dodging. The fights that do force you to learn are all fun and rewarding, and there are plenty of them.

Visual effects can be a bit much at times, as your screen can get covered with blue lasers and explosions, leaving you unable to see anything other than the HUD. However, for the majority of the game, all weapon effects look incredible.

Maps are good but are recycled a lot. You'll find that many missions use the same levels you've already done, but this time you're starting at the end and going to the beginning. It doesn't take away from the enjoyment, but it would have been nice to see original levels instead.

Truly revolutionary and one of the games the next generation of Masters will be building on. Lots of new weapon and encounter design I've never seen before here. Pick it up if you are a Fromsoft, Shooter, or action-adventure-platformer fan, Game Designer, or anyone obsessed with the medium.

As an armored core or mech fan, it depends on how much you like fast mechs, as these mechs are big, but very, VERY fast and the controls are much more like a typical video game than typical mechsim, or previous AC games. Also as a Fromsoft Fan yet more proof people other than miyazaki there are masters of the craft too.

An incredible mech-action game, with phenomenal single player experience, highly recommended if you're looking for a good mecha game to fill holes gundam games couldn't. Great story, highly replayable, the bosses can get a little difficult but surprisingly tame compared to FS' other bosses, an incredible experience overall.

The PVP however has a lot to be desired; poor balancing, unoptimal netcode, and meta that favor the extremes and specialized builds. Armored Core 6 is a rebirth of what was once thought to be lost to time forever.  As a long time AC fan, this game does an amazing job at capturing what made us fall in love with the games while introducing new mechanics, new concepts, and new experiences.  Stunning visuals, a story that makes you think and feel, and you get to enjoy it all while piloting 4 story tall mechs, with enough customization to suit any play style.

To address the gripes of some long time fans - yes.  It introduces Dark Souls style boss mechanics.  There is a dodge system.  There is a sword.  There is stagger.  True fans of the series know how these games have evolved through each iteration.  This is not AC4A.  This is a new generation of Armored Core game. 

To new fans: Welcome, and I sincerely hope you enjoy this game as much as I do.  

To FromSoftware: Thank you.  All I ever dreamed of was another entry into this series.  And I couldn't be more thrilled.

To Elden Ring: Thank you for being such an amazing game, and selling so many copies, that it led to the development of AC6.

TLDR: Solid 9/10 game, stunning release by FromSoftware as always.  Mech fans, AC fans, Elden Ring fans, Dark Souls fans, and enjoyers of challenging, rewarding gameplay will all have a good time with this one.

AC6 is a perfect example of a game that makes me wish for a "mixed" recommendation, because it has very much been a mixed bag for me. I will also preface my thoughts by mentioning that I have not played any other AC title, nor do I have much experience with mecha games in general. I bought this game based on Fromsoft's pedigree and the intriguing premise.

So, the first thing that was apparent to me even from the reveal trailer, is that the game has a fantastic art style. Although Rubicon is a rather bleak world (being basically an icy wasteland), it is nonetheless consistently impressive to behold with its abundance of dizzying megastructures that feel like they might well reach into the atmosphere. I frequently stop and think about the environments from a human scale and it does often feel downright comical just how big these buildings are, but without knowing more about the setting I can suspend my disbelief and simply buy that, in this setting, we have the technology to easily construct continent-sized structures. It certainly makes for cool environments.

However, I think I would have appreciated occasional glances at the world from an actual human viewpoint to help put the scale of the mecha action into perspective. Maybe walking sections would have been out of place, but cutscenes could have benefited here - even just seeing 621 talk to Walter in the hangar face to face, or from a console, would have been cool. Or seeing humans in the actual levels, running away from the action or even making futile attempts to fight back. Future Cop LAPD had you trample human criminals with your police mech, great fun and underlined the might of your war machine well.

The music in the game is serviceable, though it hardly stood out to me. I literally just finished the game and I cannot recall a single melody. It's all very subdued sci-fi background noise as far as I'm concerned.

Solid voice acting and mostly solid writing with a, I'll call it a serviceable story. I can appreciate that I have only seen 1 out of 3 endings so the nuances will surely elude me, but having done one playthrough (Fires of Raven ending) and reading what lore the game offered me, I get the general gist of it all but I struggle to feel really invested in any of it. It's all very grand-scale concepts (the inhumanity of war, the extremes of corporate greed, the exploitation of nature), mixed with some distinctly sci-fi magic elements (with Coral being a wonder resource that is both a seemingly infinite energy source, as well as a sentient hivemind entity). But, similar to what I mentioned earlier, I miss the human perspective. Players develop something of a rapport with Ayre (one of the "ghosts" in the Coral), but at no point are we given an iota of personality from 621, nor do we ever see a face. We're hardly given appreciable motivations for why people do what they do. There's some backstory in the arena profiles for AC pilots, but it is so, so meaningless when you just expose it in 2-3 sentences in an optional text blurb.

In short, I really miss the "human" element in the story. Mechs are cool, grand concepts are cool, but all of this needs to be grounded in a way that makes it relatable to human scales and human feelings. I will add that, I think, this is a deliberate approach by Fromsoft since these symptoms are rampant in their other games (chiefly, their Souls and adjacent titles), and I'm not a fan of it there either. Elden Ring's story would hit much harder if they made me care about the Tarnished and their relationship with the denizens of the Lands Between, and the same can be said for AC6. It is so difficult to care about a silent protagonist who operates in a world of half-truths and omissions, interacting with forces and concepts well beyond human scale. The building blocks for a gripping experience are here, but the mortar that binds it all is absent - deliberately so.

They don't want to do this, so at the end of the day I'm left with an impression of "Coral is kinda cool I guess" and "wowzers, those sure were some nice explosions!", yet craving that satisfying feeling I get after, say, finishing Deus Ex: Human Revolution, or a Witcher game - stories that actually have something to say about the human condition, beyond providing spectacle and world-endangering crises.

With regards to the gameplay, I will say that the pacing of content is also short of satisfying. I'm just not a big fan of piecemeal, instanced missions that take 5-10 minutes, then booting me back into the hangar (especially when it makes no narrative sense at all in later missions). The world feels surprisingly small because of it, in spite of the vast scale it promises through its graphics. This is further reinforced by the heavy reuse of maps from various angles and with various enclosures, making it feel like the game is really taking place in ~5-6 relatively small locations tops.

The placement of fights in the arena is perhaps the biggest offender in terms of pacing, though. I was stuck for 3 chapters on one of the "weakest" enemies - Maeterlinck. Took me, I dunno, 20 or 30 attempts to beat that bitch. But every enemy before her, I beat in one try. Every enemy after her, I beat in 1 or 2 tries (the ninja-inspired mech took 3). She is such an anomaly in her placement. Should have been at the #1 spot if you ask me, not 5th from the bottom.

I also feel that the arena was a lackluster inclusion, conceptually. Wouldn't it be more interesting to maybe talk to these characters and build a rapport before fighting them? Furthermore, some of the arena foes you do fight in actual missions. Don't see a good reason to fight them early in the arena, or rematch them here later (except maybe as a sort of VR boss rush gauntlet mode for people who want it). Just seems strange as a game element, as if they had all these mech fights planned out but no time to actually put them into real missions, so they just dumped them all into a list of generic arena fights.

Lastly, and I admit that this is entirely based on my own preferences, I was just not a fan of the general gameplay conceit that your build determines victory or defeat before combat even begins. That might be a little extreme, and I'm sure people beat all kinds of bosses with all kinds of builds, but it is generally true that the difference between bringing the "right" build and not, is the difference between beating a boss easily in 1-2 tries or beating your head against a wall for hours or days on end.

Personally, I don't really like the experience of discovering that the next roadblock boss just straight up counters every weapon I've got equipped and now I need to figure out which of the dozens of weapons and hundreds of combinations is the "good" loadout to just beat it without trouble. For the final boss I just googled the solution online, found the "meta" build, used it and, sure enough, won in 2 tries.

Not saying that's necessarily a bad feature, but it's a particular taste - and it ain't mine.

In conclusion I would say my time with the game alternated between decent and mediocre, depending on my current frustration level. Some of the narrative things I wished the game had were neglected, whilst its core gameplay brought me middling enjoyment at best, or frustration at worst when it gets hard. The game's difficulty in general is very much a pendulum that swings between "trivially easy" and "CBT" with little rhyme or reason (see the Maeterlinck example).

Even so, AC6 carries the quality standard that Fromsoft is known for, and I'm sure that people who do enjoy the customization and adaptation aspect of this kind of mech game will have a really good time with it. Just because it wasn't all that for me, doesn't mean that I don't recommend the game on those grounds. Decide for yourself if the game's design principles, as well as its strengths and weaknesses, appeal to you or not.

Armored Core for Steam: Reviving Mecha Excellence

Armored Core makes a triumphant return to PC gaming with its debut on Steam, bringing with it all the elements that made the series a beloved icon of mecha combat. This latest installment revitalizes the franchise with upgraded graphics, seamless online integration, and the same deep customization and thrilling gameplay that fans have cherished for years.

From the moment you dive into Armored Core on Steam, you're greeted with a visually stunning world rendered in crisp detail. The mechs themselves are a marvel to behold, each intricately designed and fully customizable down to the smallest component. Whether you're tweaking your arsenal of weapons, adjusting armor plating for optimal defense, or fine-tuning your mech's mobility, the level of customization is unparalleled and ensures that every player can create a mech that suits their personal style and strategy.

The gameplay mechanics are as polished as ever, offering a blend of intense action and strategic depth. Piloting your mech feels responsive and fluid, whether you're navigating through sprawling urban environments or engaging in high-stakes battles against formidable opponents. The controls are intuitive, yet allow for nuanced maneuvering and precise targeting, making each encounter a test of skill and tactics.

Never played armored core before but this game rules. Customization and combat are extremely deep without feeling overwhelming. That signature from software art direction and boss battle design is in your face in the best way, and the story is probably the most straightforward of previous fromsoftware titles. 

When my imaginary girlfriend tells me to get in the robot, I listen.

[h1] Overall Review [/h1]
High quality game all around. Beautiful graphics, excellent sound design, and a perfect sense of scale. The game offers much more than you would expect, including a base game, a New Game +, and a New Game ++ all with unique and engaging content. Well worth $60, with very few flaws.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

Like what you would expect from a FromSoft game, the core gameplay loop heavily revolves around combat, which is done immensely well. The excellent sound design and graphics come together to make every hit feel weighty and fitting for a battle on a mecha-scale. (Nothing feels better than landing a solid, deep cutting melee attack.) Gameplay is very smooth, and every combat is a puzzle that can either be brute forced with skill, or made a little easier with the right build.

Again, true to FromSoft fashion, this game shines the most in its boss battles. Most bosses pose a unique challenge that will either require adaptation, skill, or both to overcome. Luckily, the game makes it very easy to adapt to bosses by making the in game store have a 100% refund rate, allowing you to just sell your current build and swap to one you think will be more fitting at no cost to your progress.

[h1] Storyline [/h1]

In terms of story, this game really isn't meant to be about the story. It's a game all about being in a giant mech and kicking ass, are you really here for an in depth and captivating storyline? If you are, you won't be disappointed. The plot and characters are simple on their surface, but paying attention to notes and dialogue will reveal a good amount of intrigue. If you allow yourself to become invested, some of the story decisions to be made throughout the game will be truly heart wrenching and emotionally impactful. Furthermore, many mysteries of your first playthrough are expanded on and explained throughout NG+ and NG++.

[h1] Bonus Features [/h1]

True to it's origins, Armored Core 6 has robust multiplayer and cosmetic options. You can customize the appearance of your Core down to very fine details, color, decorations, and shininess.
You can also pit your mechs off against your friends 1v1 or in 3v3 battles. There is also an online competitive arena, but as I haven't gotten into it yet, I will not comment. Point is, if you want to battle your friends and look good doing it, this game has you covered.

[h1] Criticism [/h1]

While this game is very good, it isn't perfect, and I have two minor complaints.
Firstly, about 20 percent of boss fights take place in arenas that seem large, but are actually enclosed rather tightly by invisible walls. In a game all about mobility and dodging incoming projectiles, hitting these walls not only sucks due to their immersion breaking effects, but also because you are going to get hit by the ~30 or 40 missiles you were trying to dodge when you slammed into that wall. It also really doesn't help when the bosses themselves are allowed to go outside of and attack you from beyond those walls.


[b] [VERY MINOR SPOILER AHEAD] [/b]

Even more unfortunately, the tutorial boss suffers the most from this flaw. The first boss you face during the game is a large helicopter, and as you'd expect with FromSoft, just because it's a tutorial boss, doesn't mean it's going to be easy. As a new player it poses a decent challenge, but the biggest challenge is in just how much time it will spend camping outside of the invisible arena walls barraging you with missiles. If you don't want to spend more time than you have to just to start the game, I recommend learning to hide from the helicopter when it does this in order to force it back into the playable area.

[b] [MINOR SPOILER END] [/b]

Secondly, there are A LOT of numbers and statistics to keep track of when assembling your mech, many of which are not explained in any tutorial. It can be confusing when you are trying to assemble the mech that you want, but keep hitting limitations that you don't understand, and remain unexplained. My recommendation is to do one of the following:
A: Spend some time using the "Give context" feature in the mech assembly area in order to get a grasp on what the numbers actually mean.
B: Make use of premade builds and then tweak them to your needs 
C: Watch a youtube tutorial explaining how AC design limitations and features work.

Fantastic AC game. I've played since the original came out in 97, with most of my time spent on 3 and 4, and this is probably my favorite. As long as you know and are comfortable the mechanics, the game is only as hard as your build makes it. YouTube is full of build help videos for those new to the series or those finding it difficult. They've also taken a note from Elden Ring and made each mission super open so it gives this grandiose feeling to each map. I guess my only complaint is that the 1v1 arena mode is really bland and comes off as little more than a way to test builds against different NPC ACs. Older titles had you fight in an actual arena with set pieces (a giant lifted highway over a little colony town, for instance) to hide behind, in, under etc. This is just an open space in what seems to be a VR arena or something. Just flat and boring.

Besides that, If they continue with this design direction, I will continue to throw money at them.

Armored Core VI: Fires Of Rubicon is my first introduction to the series and also to mech games. It is a wonderful game, tons amount of fun. The very first mission, while frustrating for absolute beginners like myself, is a great way to show what is to come, what future missions will be like.

Half of the time when playing this game, you'd be busy building your mech, your AC, finding parts that fit your playstyle and what fits the situation. You can't put everything into one basket; you can't equip all best parts into one AC. Building an AC requires compromises. High output damage forces you to equip slow mobility. And I like that feature. It makes you think more and come up with something to make up for the compromises.

The difficulty in the game is not linear; it doesn't go easy to hard from first mission to last. The first chapter is already very difficult and a huge wall (heh) to overcome. The difficulty is scattered; you'll get a hard mission, then an easy one, then another easy one before coming a harder mission. It is almost unpredictable, though I guess that goes pretty well with the theme of the game: "Expect the unexpected".

I have no interest in the PvP arena, but that brings the attention to the fact that there is no official Co-op mode. You are paired with NPCs in a few missions yet you can't play missions with your friends together. I feel like this is a missed opportunity.

Overall, it is a great game with a heartbreaking storyline, very much expected from FromSoftware!

This is definitely one of the very few great games that has released in the past 10 years. There is very little negative I have to say about this game, as it is a good sequel that improves and expands on the predecessors. Thankfully Fromsoft left souls mechanics out of the game for the most part showing that they can still make good games completely separate from souls. The sheer amount of build variety was one of the big selling points, and it does not disappoint. If you become stuck in any part of this game, you are encouraged to try different parts or weapons and can sell back any parts for a full refund instead of beating your head against the wall for hours. In addition to this, the game is full of varied missions, enemies, and bosses that offer both spectacle and challenge. If that wasn't enough, there are alternate missions and completely new missions to be unlocked in the first two new game plus cycles. The soundtrack does have many forgettable tracks for the basic missions, but the major parts of the game have genuinely impressive electronic music.

If I had to assign a Game Of The Year for 2023, this would be it. For anyone who has never played a mech game, this would be the one I recommend. It controls exceptionally well and has great gameplay to match it, putting it leagues above any other mech game for the most part. The visuals are, to be frank, the best I have seen out of a game, the only other contenders I could think of would be God of War (2018). The environments match the graphics, being incredibly diverse and deep in their construction.

Regardless, despite how FUCKING BEAUTIFUL this game is, it runs incredibly well even on low power devices. As well, the way each person plays the game will be different, with customization that has lead me astray for hours just building cool designs or making something more fun for me to play, like a melee focused build. 

The missions in the game, and the story as a whole, is subtle but well crafted. By the end of some endings (there are multiple), I was either screaming with joy or on the verge of tears. The characters were surprisingly interesting as well. The story, or at least one play through of the game isn't very long at all, being 20-30 hours, even if there are 3 separate endings you can play through (each of which go through different missions and diverge). 

When I am not playing this game, I am thinking of playing this game. Don't even get me started on some of the songs on the unique but great soundtrack of the game. Also, I've never properly experience a bug or crash since I got the game, so there's that.

TLDR: Expect boss difficulty spikes and be prepared to spend potential hours trying to best one boss. Otherwise, the game has incredible gameplay, story, visuals and is just genuinely fun.

The game is great from top to bottom. The combat is unlike anything I've seen before, silky smooth, and there are a million ways you can beat the game. The story is also very good.

This is a really hard review to write for me. There is so much good about this game, but for everything that is good about it, there is a stupid decision made with the game design that leaves me disappointed. I will organize this review into different sections for the purpose of clarity.

***WARNING: Slight spoilers ahead, nothing major or super important though so you won't miss anything if you decide to get it*** 

STORY:
The story of AC6 is that you are Raven, an Armored Core pilot that has crash landed on the planet Rubicon. You do the bidding of your handler, Walter, and are participating in this war going on for a resource on the planet called Coral. Coral apparently caused a catastrophic event called the Fires of Ibis which burned the entire planet and surrounding star system 50 years ago. All the Coral was thought to be burnt up until it is detected on Rubicon again years later and corporations rush to be the first to seize it. There are different factions warring over this resource and the missions will have you taking the side of a faction in one, and then fighting against that same faction in the next. You have almost no loyalties and do the bidding of whoever will pay the most for your service. It's an interesting concept switching sides so often in a game as that is usually never the case so I did find that aspect interesting.

The problems begin with the game's horrible lack of explanation for things. What is Coral? How exactly does it work? Well, even after finishing the game you will be left guessing because it never explains what exactly it is at all other than it is some sort of energy source that allowed humanity to rapidly advance. It never explains how it is flammable, what caused the Fires of Ibis, what "Ibis" even is, or anything like that. It makes things even more confusing when you come into contact with some Coral and start to hear this voice in your head from then on. According to the subtitles the voice is someone named Ayre and she speaks to you on missions and in the hangar; calling out enemies and giving you directions. After finishing the game and still not getting a sensible explanation for who exactly she is, I looked it up on the Wiki and apparently she is a disembodied Rubiconian, which is just a person from Rubicon. HUH??? That makes zero sense. That's like saying if you smell diesel fuel you can speak to your dead grandmother. Who the hell thought this was good lore? It makes even less sense that she gives you enemy callouts and directions since how do you know where all these enemies are without a physical body that has, you know, EYES??? How are you seeing this and talking to me? Who thought this made sense? When people die on Rubicon do they somehow become part of the Coral? Is it made from human souls? The world will never know because THIS GAME IS PISS POOR AT EXPLAINING THINGS. I feel like this is a common problem in FromSoftware games where the gameplay is cool but the story just absolutely makes zero sense. It's like instead of having many cohesive thoughts that all interconnect, they just throw a bunch of random story elements together and consider it a well though-out, finished story, which it is not at all. You are not given any reason to care at all about the planet Rubicon or any of the characters and the largely mediocre voice acting doesn't help. It is such a shame too because visually, Rubicon is one of the coolest looking locations I've seen in a game. I LOVE megastructures and this game reminded me so much of BLAME!. I really wanted to get into it story wise but there just really isn't anything there to get into. It's pretty disappointing. Overall the story is poor and needed a lot more thought put into it and time developing it. Oh, and there are also 3 different endings so you will have to replay the game THREE DIFFERENT TIMES in order to see all of them (at least you keep all the mech parts and stuff you unlocked).

GAMEPLAY:
The gameplay is the better part of the game. Japanese and Western takes on mech games are very different. Western mech games often focus on mechs being slow, hulking machines with hard hitting attacks, while Japanese mech games are usually much more Gundam-like, with fast paced combat and high movement speeds. FromSoftware, being Japanese, made this game in the latter fashion. The combat is very addictive and in my opinion is the strongest part of the game. It's satisfying and fast paced and you have many different weapons to choose from that all really do feel different. It's fun to customize your mech and they give you lots of ways to do so, which I appreciate. I like how the different legs really affect how your mech handles. You can choose from bipedal (jack of all trades), reverse joint (can jump really high), tetrapod (can hover in the air), and tank (slower but has high health). I don't think I've played a mech game where your choices made your mech actually feel extremely different to play so I like how that was done. There is even a Black Ops 2 style emblem creator so you can make your own custom emblems and put them on your mech or set one as your pilot emblem. I also like that none of the customization options are locked behind a paywall. There are NO MICROTRANSACTIONS in this game, which I really appreciate.

The levels do have some issues. For example, the pacing is terrible. In the very first mission you have to fight a hard boss before you have even gotten a chance to grasp the controls of this game. It's not just an easy throw-away boss fight either, it's actually decently difficult and I can see it being frustrating and off-putting to new players. I do like how it sets the tone for the game, that this place is out to kill you, but there is no excuse for placing such a hard boss in the literal TUTORIAL level. I feel bad for those playing this on console because it is even harder to deal with the boss (and really just everything in this game) on a controller. If you end up getting the game, mouse and keyboard is definitely the way to play. Anyways, the tutorial throws the pacing way off since the next few missions are easy and can be considered a joke compared to the boss fight so it just feels like the events are very out of order. The game is also separated into 5 different Chapters, with some of them being long and containing lots of missions while others are extremely short. For example, Chapter 2 only has 3 missions in it while the next Chapter has 12. All of these issues contribute to the pacing just feeling odd and you don't really get a good sense of how far along you are in the story due to them.

I also wish there was more multiplayer functionality. You can fight other players but there is no way to do co-op on missions, no PvE mode, or anything like that. It's a shame since the combat is the strongest part of the game and it would be fun to do it with others in more ways than just the one.

Also, why is the maximum FPS only 120? FromSoftware is aware that monitors above 120 hertz exist, right? Come on guys it's not 2011 anymore, this is unacceptable in 2024.

CONCLUSION:
I would probably give this game a 6.5 out of 10. The combat is good, but the story is so bad there's no way to care about the combat outside of it just being satisfying to rain down missles on things. The game has some serious issues that make it to where I can't really recommend it, despite it also having some good going for it. I guess if you don't care about story and just want big robot go brrrr then get it and you will have fun, but if you need a good motive/story to get behind a game and to care about the world you are entering in to like I do, I would stay away.

Not at all open world or even semi linear.  Entirely mission based including main storyline encounters and progression.

Includes a store that gets better gear as you progress, an upgrade store for "evo" chips that increase some of your passive abilities (nothing really amazing), an area to test out your new gear before you start a mission (sortie) and a very basic "arena" where you fight digital versions of bosses which is the sole source of evo chips.

Somehow this very, very basic setup is still an engaging storyline that I was invested in to the point that I pushed through some very hard sorties (mostly the defense ones and a couple bosses that require you to rethink your whole build) mostly because I wanted to see the rest of the story.

Definitely a good game to play if you're into gearing up, gearing out and story-involved gameplay.

TLDR: its really good

Anyways,
A few years ago, before this game came out I decided to play the old Armored Core games because I had a craving to play some "mech games" and they didn't really grab me, though I saw the appeal and I had some fun for a while. When Fromsoft said that they wanted to do things other than soulslikes after Eldin Ring, I started getting hyped because I was really hoping they'd take all the experience working on action games and apply them to the Armored Core IP, and I ended up actually being right.

There is some DNA from other Fromsoft games here and it serves the game well. The laser swords are not only usable but fun to use, and the stagger system leads to a lot of hype moments in combat. While a lot of people love the combat of the old games, I prefer this faster style of combat.

I've seen a lot of people say this game is too easy, but I think the difficulty is pretty solid. There is a lot of weapon variety and they are all viable if you can integrate them into a build properly, and I much prefer this to the old games where it felt like half of the arsenal was kind of junk but maybe that's just a skill issue on my part. Honestly I wonder if a bunch of people are looking up OP meta builds to play this and that is where the difficulty complaints are coming from. I found my first playthrough to be very challenging, the second one was much easier, and the third one was the easiest save for the end, though I think this has to do with a combination of getting better at building decent mechs and just getting better at the gameplay.

Also the industrial megastructure aesthetic is awesome and I just wanted to say that.

AC6 is probably the best mech game I've ever played buy it if you want to play a good mech game.

Phenomenal game. Fluid controls, responsive movement that doesn't take away from the scale, combat with real impact, and a huge amount of customisation options that can change the way you play and approach the game. I can't think of another game within the last decade or two that even begins to approach the atmospheric design in AC6. The writing is excellent while staying lean and unobtrusive, and the voice acting is superb. If you enjoy singleplayer experiences in videogames, not playing this would be to do yourself a catastrophic disservice. The only real weakness of the game is how barebones the multiplayer is - definitely a step down from ACV in that regard, but there's still a lot of mileage to be had playing duels.

I had never played an AC title before this one. It took me over an hour to beat the first level.

But the gameplay is good. It's really good. And the graphics are crisp and detailed, immersing you in a deliciously cold, dark world of steel and misery. The lighthearted moments hit so much harder in such a bleak setting, and the story moves along at a fast clip. You can always linger longer, replay missions, fight in the arena, tweak your build. But when you're ready to move on, the story doesn't linger or dawdle.

So much of the game is spent in the garage, customizing your loadout and paint job, trying out different weapons and tweaking stat bars to squeeze every ounce of efficiency out of your mech. Then you go raging through a mission, get a feel for what worked and what didn't, and go back to tweak some more. It's a bit like being a race car driver, spending hours tuning everything to perfection before blasting through a race. Except instead of a race track, you're shooting your way through a mission in a blaze of missiles and giant energy swords with a super-weapon the size of a building.

I went into AC6 with raw determination, and the crucible of Rubicon refined it into skill. Going back to replay the first mission hours later and annihilating the boss there, using nothing but the starting gear, was a moment of catharsis. I had learned, and I had grown strong.

Every mecha fan's wet dream, honestly. A pretty far departure from previous AC titles, but still distinct enough from other Fromsoft series' to retain its own natural identity and reputation. Customization is next level, and the game's difficulty and playstyle as a whole tends to be dictated almost entirely by how you choose to design your own war machine. Multiplayer is limited; as it always tends to be with Fromsoft games - but I do find it interesting how you have to progress to about the halfway point in your first playthrough to actually unlock the multiplayer in the first place. I'm not sure why that decision was made, but it feels fitting to have to fight your way far enough to earn the privelege to compete against other pilots.

About 30 hours of playtime to get all three endings if you're a returning/veteran pilot. I'd imagine about double that if you're a first time player who's still learning the ropes and taking your time to explore the worldbuilding. This game has buckets upon buckets of lore within it - but it tends to outright stray away from putting it in your face, forcing you to explore and put the puzzle pieces together yourself if you really want to know the true story. That's something I like, no doubt.

So far, every update to the game that adds additional content has been entirely free. But I would gladly pay money for a formal DLC like the one that Elden Ring received. Fromsoft never lets you down with their single player titles.

Game's decent, building mechs and trying out different weapons and parts is fun. Combat is fast paced and pretty decent even though the lock-on system feels a bit clunky and unintuitive and I'm not a particularly big fan of the stagger mechanics.

The boss battles are mostly enjoyable except some of them do feel a bit cheap and like they pidgeonhole you into using certain builds (tracks for CEL 240, quads for Sea Spider for example) which feels a bit odd for a game that states you can design your build around how you like to play.

Story is... well kinda dumb, there are quite a few missions where I thought "why the hell am I doing this?" and a lot of other plot elements which really don't make any sense from a logical perspective. Just completed my first playthrough in 24 hours and that was with getting all parts and clearing all the arenas, so the longevity is pretty limited, especially for a game that still costs £50-60 if you don't get it on sale.

There is a NG+ however I can't say I'm particularly drawn to play it, once you finish your first playthrough you pretty much have everything and more money than you know what to do with, there are two more parts unlockable at the very end of NG+ playthrough but they're not that exciting and I don't feel it's worth another 20 hours just for that. I think it might be partly because the format isn't greatly suited to NG+, most RPG's that have NG+ have XP which gives you an incentive to keep going where AC6 only really has those 2 more parts.

Overall it's decent, wouldn't buy it full price but if you have an itch for a mech game a sale purchase probably won't feel like wasted money.

It has been a long time, perhaps since I was a kid, that a game has give me such a strong visceral reaction as this game. FromSoft have absolutely knocked it out of the park by ignoring (rightfully so) their habits in the Souls games, and giving the ARMORED CORE series its due diligence. See, AC is a very different game and franchise from the Souls series, and so I am sure that, like myself, a lot of fans were waiting to see if the AC series would turn into a reskin of Souls gameplay due to FromSoft's obvious success with that franchise. However, that is not the case. They stayed true to the formula of this franchise and expanded and perfected it to levels I dreamt of. I am proud to play this game, and no other words in this review can do the experience of seeing and fighting Balteus for the first time justice.

Do yourself a favor, get a license, and hop into your core, pilot. There are jobs to be done...

The game does not even tell you what is needed for S-rank, you can have much better payout, not even use repair kits, shorter time than some youtubers and somehow end up with A-rank. It is a pity because the mech customizations and the 1-on-1 arena are cool can try different builds and what not. I got every achievement except 1 and cant be bothered anymore. I got through 3 endings (a lot of repeat too mind you) in under 30 hours. This is the same price as Elden Ring, which is easily 150-200 hours of content??? Only get it if it is on a deep discount like 50% off.

The challenge begins when you just try to load into the first mission and got hit by an endless black loading screen. Spent ~20 mins to fix it and now it's fine.
Overall, it's gameplay oriented game, and it definitely delivers here. It's fun and dynamic. It's not as hardcore as any other Fromsoft title. So far, there was only one boss that really pissed me off(and it's on 28th hour through game). It was the only time when I needed to do a 5 min research to find which weapon[s] would be most efficient in that particular case. Usually, when I struggled with some boss - it's a)build issue (and you can easily adjust it mid-mission) b)tactics and the way I was approaching boss.
The customization options for mech are quite broad. From 30 hours in the game I've spent ~1/3 just playing around with different builds, weapons and modules for the mech. 
The missions length is just fine.  And a plot is not as messed up as in any demon/dark souls game(it has clear, understandable dialogs). As a matter of fact, it's pretty straightforward, although it leaves some space open for interpretation.

Regarding soundtrack. I enjoyed it.I think some, or even most boss fights would have benefited by having unique ost. Still, there are few that had those, end they were truly special and enjoyable. Main menu ost and it's sub-menus(e.g. the one with mech config) also contain really nice soundtrack, which is a big +, since you spend a lot of time in shop and customisation menus.

I really enjoyed this game but didn't find the challenge I expected.  Breezed through the campaign and arena mode.  I think the online mode is probably pretty tough but I bought this for the single player challenge.  

Overall, its a great game with solid combat mechanics and allows for very versatile builds - but not overly difficult.

I want to be 100% clear that even though I don't think I'd recommend this game, this is objectively a very good game. Personally, maybe even a perfect game. I know that may sound confusing, just indulge me.

Armored Core VI (AC6) is very well polished, mechanically deep, fast paced, action packed and produced from a game publisher whose pedigree is elite. I don't think I need to speak much on FromSoft's ability to be highly consistent in quality. Begin as C4-621, an augmented AC pilot beneath the authority of Handler Walter. You have no agency, no power, not even your body beyond the drive to become a highly skilled and efficient mercenary. Become the ultimate pilot or perhaps transcend your fate as a mere slave to this world. Either way, destroy any one who stands in your way. Complete the mission. 

Shit's pretty invigorating right? So, why do I not readily recommend it? 

The caveat is that I'm confident that AC6 has a tendency to be a very niche experience and therefore, difficult to objectively judge, and I believe it shows. (As always, you are your own person, believe what you want, I have no responsibility to provide you with the most accurate data in the world about AC6) After some quick skimming online, it's apparent to me that AC6 is often overshadowed by its less mechanical FromSoft siblings. It's not the hardest game, it's not the highest rated game, it's definitely not the most popular game, some websites didn't even rate it on their miscellaneous lists.

Some issues I can foresee for new players is that they might feel somewhat dissatisfied or confused when starting, especially as some of the first levels can feel extremely easy or far too short. Or when they reach a difficult boss, they feel disgruntled that they have to change their playstyle/mech rather than being able to purely outskill the game. Or it can feel somewhat bland or toneless in its setting despite the inspired art direction. This is all by design. AC6 implores you to try everything, replay everything, collect everything, learn everything, and avoid as much damage as you can and push through it or brute force your machine through the game. Its not impossible, just unlikely to do. And the world is bleak, it is toneless, this is a world where humanity has sunk to the wretches of capitalism and pure cold heartless logic remains in the wastelands of Humanity's creation. You own nothing, not even your very flesh.

Its a difficult game to place that asks a high price for a justly well produced game. But arguably not a readily accessible one compared to its siblings. All I can say is, I implore you to try. I really liked it, I felt that I played enough of it I needed but I'll never say I won't revisit it. 

That being said, I would not be surprised if you didn't like it.

I loved the game. Visuals are absolutely stunning, the sheer scale of the environment and even bosses is nearly unprecedented and it probably has the best mech combat I've ever played, but unfortunately I feel like the boss nerfs post-release made the game too easy. 

I was hoping I'd actually have to learn the different types of weapons, damage types and movesets and adjust my mech accordingly, but in the end I more or less ran the same build with some minor adjustments throughout the whole game [spoiler] (2 cannons on the back, 2 machine guns/mini guns/flamethrowers as primary and focusing everything on QB speed) [/spoiler] and breezed through it without much issue. I only really started dying/learning the fight at the final boss of my first playthrough, since it was just extremely hard to track the movements when your screen is filled with red the entire time, but even that only took around 15 tries till I got through (which isn't a lot considering the fights took <3min each). 

Perhaps I accidentally found a meta build, but even when I switched it up it didn't feel much harder. Honestly, the hardest part was getting S-Rank in [spoiler] Attack the Refueling Base [/spoiler] because that mission has extremely tight timings for whatever reason.

Still, as I said the visuals and gameplay are amazing, so as long as you can appreciate that even with a bit less of the typical FromSoft punishment, it's absolutely worth the money.

I just wanted a call sign of my own...

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]

Game is fun. Fromsoft games tend to focus on a specific game aspect and excel as far as possible in that. Sekiro? Combat. Elden Ring? Exploration. Dark Souls? Excels at being Dark Souls. This game focuses on build variety and experimentation. You ever play a Fromsoft game and got envy when your 60 hour toon can't equip a really sick ass weapon cos you didn't level a specific stat? You ever play a fromsoft game and pre-plan a build from scratch cos you wanna exploit a specific mechanic? AC6 plays around that idea; building the right mech for the right job is the game loop here. 

[h2] Mechanics [/h2]

Some mechanisms aren't explained well (as is typical of From Software) but the shimmy of it is that this is a mech game balanced around light mech (zoom around the level and kill things as fast as possible); medium mech (jack-off-all-trades); and heavy tank mech (slow but big boom boom). There's also a 4th option of tetrapod (flying fortress of death like Ghibli's Castle in the Sky). 

The additional mechanic is the idea of Sekiro-esque posture bar (aka ACS). Normal shots have their damaged on the healthbar reduced by armor. Break through ACS, and the attack is 100% direct on the healthbar. Conventional weapons do the most damage on ACS, but is balanced by a significant normal hit reduction. Energy weapons are do more normal hit damange, but contributes less to ACS buildup. In addition, pulse damage does direct damage onto shields. There's a bring-the-right-gun-to-a-gunfight kind of system here. 

The best way to learn the combat without getting overloaded by information is to check the Official Bandai Namco beginner guide on this game, which I've found to be an excellent resource.

[h2] Game-design [/h2] 

This game's levels are short-burst and designed for you to quickly murder robots and move on to the next checkpoint. The level designs are varied and bring you to some pretty interesting locales. The basic enemy is generally cannon fodder, the more annoying enemies are...annoyances but help keep things interesting. Death brings you to a checkpoint nearby so it rarely if ever feels punishing to die. I like that part, since there's a huge de-emphasis on exploration in the levels, that restarting from scratch would result in a negative experience. This is very much the experience of Ace Combat where you feel a rush from killing enemies, and the game wants you to get in there and kill things for your satisfaction. 

The game breaks up this monotony mainly by scattering very good boss fights with certain gimmicks. These guys are tough, even with the right build - and perform sort of a skill check whilst also keeping that cinematic feel of a boss fight in a Fromsoft game. Cool game.
